country:
None
text:
My boyfriend is a celiac (allergic to wheat gluten) and so I was looking for a cornbread recipe to use for Eggs Benny. I stumbled upon this recipe and decided to substitute the flour for soy flour. I also realized halfway through that I didn't have any white sugar, so I used brown sugar instead... After all that, I baked it for 30 minutes and was surprised! Despite the strange-tasting batter, the cornbread turned out amazing! Just a tip for anyone using this recipe, use a pot instead of a pan to melt the butter and mix the ingredients into and there will be no mess with blending the ingredients - wheat or no wheat.

text:
This turned out really good. I followed fairly closely although I added 1 tsp of baking powder with the soda. Full tsp of salt. I used white cornmeal but can't see how that would make a difference. I melted the butter in micro in large bowl (vs a large skillet) and went from there. Used half brn sugar & half white. I did add a few spices and cooked in my hot, lard greased cast iron skillet. At 375 it was done in 25 minutes. Very good, nice crust. Moist and not too sweet for me. Not your typical 'choke on it' dry cornbread (which I do NOT like). I'm thinking some chopped chili or jalapeno peppers would incorporate nicely. Will use this recipe with my minor changes from now on. Love this stuff with a spicy hot bowl of chili - Yum!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tastes great, changed a few things however.  I made it with half a stick (1/4 cup) of butter originally and 1/2 cup of sugar with 50/50 cornmeal and flour.  It was great but cakey. Not bad at all.  The second time I realized my butter mistake and added the full amount and 1/2 cup of sugar with 1.25 cups of cornmeal and .75 cup of flour to make it more cornbready.  It was good, I liked the texture more but it was too buttery.  

The third time I kept the cornmeal/flour ratio to 1.25/0.75 and 1/4 cup of butter and 1/2 cup of sugar with the rest of the ingredients the same, and it was perfect. That's how I'll make it from now on. THanks!

text:
I like this recipe because it has buttermilk.  I normally use your basic, but very good "Albers Cornmeal" recipe. Here is what I recommend: butter a cast iron skillet that you have warmed in the oven for about 10 min with 1T butter.  Then add your batter and bake.  I dont understand the sequence of ingredients she has??  All ingredients go in a bowl and mix.  Add to hot skillet and you cant go wrong!

text:
This cornbread was AMAZING! Nobody could get enough and we finished an entire pan of it between the five of us! We like ours just a little sweet and that's exactly how it turned out. Just a quick word though: if some of the cornbread DOES make it into the second day, microwave it to warm it up and make it soften just a bit. The cornbread only has a shelf life of less than a week. Also, I "made" 1 cup of buttermilk by adding 1 Tbsp of vinegar to 1 cup of milk when I made the second batch and it turned out just as well.

text:
I melt the butter in a medium sized bowl in the microwave for roughly a minute so I don't end up over mixing the batter in the 8x8 pan. Then, I add the sugar and wait for it to cool for a few minutes before adding the eggs, so they won't scramble. I, also, add red and green jalapenos (at least 1 each and if you have only green peppers, that will do just fine), a couple of tablespoons of green onions, and a cup of shredded cheddar cheese before adding the remaining ingredients. Baked it for 35 minutes because we like the golden edges.

country:

text:
I grew up on the boxed Marie Callenders corn bread, which used to be decently good.  I have tried a lot of different cornbread recipes and never have they tasted this good.  I followed the recipe exactly, but baked it in a 13x9 for about 20-25 minutes and it was amazing!!  My husband grew up on crumbly dry gross cornbread and he loves this, as do both of my kids.   It's very moist and holds together well.
 I make it in a glass 8 cup measuring cup and melt the butter in the microwave to make it easier.  It is plenty sweet enough, just the way cornbread should be.  I have used margerine successfully, but just omitted the salt.  SOOO  worth making over and over!!  Leftovers are wonderful toasted in a toaster over to get them crunchy delicious and topped with a drizzle of honey.

Now I'll preface this by saying I'm not a Southerner by birth and I do love me some sweet cornbread.  This was unbelievably good.  I LOVE honey butter, but I had some on hand and didn't even use it because these were so delicious on their own, which is probably the highest compliment I can pay.  I halved the recipe and used a medium muffin pan to make cornbread muffins since I lent out my 8x8.  I baked them 14 minutes and they were perfect.  Plus, halving the recipe yielded 7 muffins, which broke down to 183 calories per muffin for those of us counting calories!

text:
Best cornbread recipe EVER!  I was a bit nervous about the sugar, so I cut it down to 1/2 cup.  It was still so sweet and delicious!  The crust on this bread was crisp while the center was light and fluffy!  MMMMM!  I doubled the recipe and melted my butter in a bowl in the microwave because I was lazy.  I don't think it made a difference.  The bake time was a bit less- only 30 min for a 9x13 pan (doubled recipe).  Rest assured I'll be making this AGAIN!  :)  Thanks for sharing!

Display Name:
sweetsuzie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/591835.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just finished dinner which was the slowcooker chicken taco soup on this site with this cornbread.  Yummmm.  I actually increased all ingredients except sugar, kept that the same, by 50% because I wanted to bake in my cast iron skillet and was afraid that it would be thin.  So glad I did the increase because it was the perfect thickness.  I didn't increase sugar because several reviewers said it was too sweet.  Glad I didn't because it was the perfect sweetness for us.  I didn't have buttermilk so added 1.5 tbs apple cider vinegar to my milk.  For cast iron skillet baking I greased it up with some butter and stuck it in a preheated oven to get hot while I got everything else ready.  Then poured the mix in the skillet once ready.  I only needed to bake for 20 min.  I think that is the census here, that 20-25 min is plenty.  Easy and tasty.  Thanks.. update 1/5/11 made with buttermilk  the 3 time and 100x better.  Stick with buttermilk.  Soooo goood...

text:
I really liked this cornbread alot.  I used 1/2 c coarse cornmeal and 1/2 c regular cornmeal (I love coarse conrmeal in cornbread, gives it an authentic rustic result).  Though next time I will try lightening the flour with cornstarch (add 1-2 T of cornstarch to your cup measurment, then fill remaining with flour), this cuts the gluten factor which gives you a lighter texture.  These weren't as light the next day, reason for the 4 stars, otherwise it would have been a 5 star.  Will definately make again.  Was geat with chili.  Yum!  This site is dangerous for those who are on a diet, like me.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is absolutely delicious! I made it gluten free by replacing the flour with Jules Gluten Free Flour (my favorite). I also took my time taking it out: Turned the oven off once it was done and opened the oven door and moved the rack out (leaving the pan on the rack for 5 to 10 minutes depending on how far it is done). This way it cools slower preventing the center from sinking which is VERY common with gluten free baked foods. I made it yesterday and there is only one piece left! This is a keeper.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this the first time to go alongside some chili I made for the schools' chili cook off. The chili was a big hit but the cornbread went even faster (and I did earn a trophy for the chili!). My youngest who isn't a bread-head like the rest of us and turns her nose up at "regular" (southern buttery drier) cornbread will DEVOUR this recipe. I've gotten so I make a double batch, bake em both in 9x13 pans, serve one, cut the second in to large cubes and freese it- some I serrve later, some I use for stuffings, crumbs, etc. It is easy, mildly sweet, very moist. Oh, please, just use the buttermilk... it's what keeps it so moist and delicious and buttermilk is not as fatty as people presume. It's worth it (and hey, you're already clogging your arteries with 1/2 cup of butter, right?!). Wish everything I made was so easy/yummy!!

country:

text:
I misplaced my regular Southern Cornbread recipe...and hunted this one up as a substitute.  Very good and close to the one I usually make.  I did however cut way back on the sugar to 1/4 cup and added about 1/2 tsp. of Baking Powder as levening.  To make the assembly easier, I melted the butter in the oven right in my 8X8 pan, and mixed the remaining ingredients in a mixing bowl to save dishes and extra steps. When the butter is melted coat the edges of the pan, pour the remaining butter into batter and stir.  Pour into hot buttered pan and bake according to the listed directions. Very moist and great with Chili.  Now that I have found this recipe I will stop looking for my old one!

My modification, however, is a MUST: bake in an iron skillet that has been preheated in oven with 1/4 cup of oil.  Add all ingredients together and pour into preheated skillet.  Better than Grandma's!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent if you're looking for the sweet and moist cornbread, not the dry bland kind. I never buy buttermilk I just add a splash of apple cider vinegar to the regular milk when I measure it out, just stir and let sit for a min or two. I love to add a dollop of sour cream for extra moistness in my cornbread when mixing. And I add a handful or two of shredded cheddar and a spoon or two of the pre diced jalapenos in a jar. Yum yum, sweet and spicey. This is my new favorite cornbread recipe!  Oh and I don't melt the butter in the skillet, I melt it in a pyrex measuring cup in the microwave, stir in sugar, and temper the eggs so they don't scramble.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/73298.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Even though I made a few personal preference changes to this recipe, I chose this recipe because I liked the equal amount of corn meal to flour.  Some recipes have too much flour.  I thought the amount of butter in the recipe would make it moist since corn bread can be a little crumbly.  The changes I made was to lower the baking temperature by 25 degrees because I used a glass pan.  I used milk soured with lemon juice because I never buy buttermilk.  Instead of using 2/3 cup of sugar I reduced the sugar to a total of 1/2 cup.  I used 6 tablespoons of white sugar and 2 tablespoons of honey.  I also let the batter sit for about 5 minutes before putting it in the oven.   I made this recipe last night to go with Slow-Cooked Chili.  It disappeared so quickly that I had to make another today.

followersCount:
0

0
madeRecipesCount:
8
favoritesCount:
160
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I not a big fan of corn bread without corn in it so I doctored this up a bit.  I also didn't have any corn meal but had Aunt Jemima Buttermilk Corn Meal Mix. It's corn meal, flour, salt and baking powder mixed together.  Two cups of the mix was used instead of 1 cup of corn meal and 1 cup of flour.  I withheld the salt since it was already in the mix. 1 can of cream corn and 4 minced chipotle peppers (remove seeds) were added to the batter to add texture and a little kick.  I used large muffin tins - poured half the batter in the tins - added a small slice of Extra Sharp Cheddar Cheese and then topping it off with additional batter.  Yummy!! I baked them for 25 minutes at 350 degrees.

text:
This is my favorite cornbread recipe. I only use 1/3 c. sugar though, and just make sour milk if I don't have buttermilk. I also bake it right in the skillet. Works great--but don't overcook! Update: I now make this with all-purpose gluten-free flour and it works great! I also reduced the sugar to 1/4 c. or no sugar at all.  I make great gluten-free cornbread stuffing with this--definitely leave out the sugar for that.

Pros:
1) Very easy to make
2) Very good taste

Cons:
1) A little too sweet
2) Flavor much too "bready", not enough "corny"
3) Very slightly on the dry side

SO, though very good indeed, this definitely does not deserve a rating of "excellent".

I used:
whole "bulgarian" buttermilk
unsalted butter

I only made two changes to this great recipe, the first was milk + lemon juice because I didn't have buttermilk, and the second was half wheat flour and half white. I like the hearty/nuttiness wheat provides.
It is a denser cornbread than I am used to, but is super tasty. I had no problems with dryness, and I will definitely make this again.

text:
Unlike so many other cornbreads out there, this was moist and had a wonderful flavor.  Be careful with the amount of sugar you add to the mix.  I think 2/3 of a cup of sugar will work for someone who has a sweet tooth.  Next time, I will reduce the sugar content to 1/2 of a cup. Other than that, this is a fantastic recipe.  10/28/2010 Update:  I baked the same recipe over.  Only this time, I baked it in my Lodge Logic 12 inch cast iron skillet.  Making cornbread in a cast iron skillet is so much better than anything else.  Once you try it, you'll never go back to your former baking pans.

text:
Extremely moist and delicious, even the day after baking! This cornbread is dense and pretty sweet., I think it is better served as muffins or as a breakfast treat with butter and honey apposed to being served with chili. I know its a bit unfair to rate recipes that you have altered, but I am going to anyways to let people know that you can change this recipe if you have dietary restrictions and still have it turn out fabulously! Instead of buttermilk I used 3/4c plain soy yogurt and 1/4c plain soymilk. Instead of butter I used non-dairy baking butter, the cornbread turned out excellent! The next time I make this I will follow the recipe exactly to see if I like it better with real butter and buttermilk. Either way, this recipe seems quite foolproof and I was not disappointed at all!

Very good.  If you use a cast iron skillet, feel free to simply spray it with cooking spray (save the calories, and there's no taste difference whatsoever). I baked both side by side for 20 minutes at 375, and all was perfect.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Gluten free too!  Personally, I felt this was too sweet, but my cornbread loving hubby said "this is the best cornbread I've ever eaten." Amazingly, he said this with my "altered recipe" - I substituted gluten-free "all purpose flour blend," used half oil for the butter, used Ener-G foods powdered egg substitute for the eggs and real maple syrup for the sugar, cutting down on the milk accordingly. 

He ALSO loved the "original" version, but again, using gluten free flours and adding ground flax seed as an alternative to make healthier. Also used stoneground, whole cornmeal, not refined.

Our friend with celiac disease recently gave me a taste of a "gluten free cornbread" that she thought was good. There was NO comparison!

So, although too rich for my tastes, appears you have a winner regardless.

text:
Yummy!  I have a son who's allergic to cow's milk, so I replaced the buttermilk with 1 cup of soy milk mixed with 1 Tablespoon of lemon juice.  I also substituted brown sugar for half of the white sugar (because I like how brown sugar tastes in corn muffins).  I  poured the batter into 12 muffin cups, then baked it in my (always too hot oven) at 350 for 20 minutes.  They turned out great - cake-like, just the way we like them - moist & sweet.

text:
This is simply amazing. It's very easy to make, and will be a hit with the crowd. Everyone that I have made this for, always goes back for a second piece. I always serve it with cinnabutter (do a search for that on here as well), which is a wonderful complimenting spread.  Edited to add: I'm still making this cornbread, and everyone still LOVES it! However, I wanted to add that last night, I didn't have cornbread. Sent my husband to the store, and he came back with half and half! Lol! Rather than sending him back, I used cold whipping cream and added about 1tbsp of lemon juice. It doesn't come out with the same texture, but rather more fluffy muffin-like. And that substitution is ALSO wonderful if you'd like it fluffier. My mother said she actually preferred it that way, where as my husband and I prefer it the original way. Either one is great though!

text:
This is the best made-from-scratch cornbread I have ever eaten. I did what a few other people recommended, adding lemon juice to milk because I didn't have buttermilk. I also added wheat flour because I was short on the cornmeal amount. I doubled the recipe and only had one cup and a little more of cornmeal. I made up the rest of the amount with wheat flour. Everyone commented on how much they loved the texture and taste and when I told them I used wheat flour they said I should do that every time. I also cooked it in a 9 by 13 pan even though I doubled the recipe. It didn't negatively affect the bread. I probably would use a little more cornmeal next time so that it has more corn taste--but not much more. So good!!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2019-10-29T15:46:57.383

12840902

roseyroseyjj

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been looking for a good cornbread recipe for a long time and this is definitely it! I used one pot to melt the butter, add the sugar, let it cool a bit, added the buttermilk, then the beaten eggs and finally the flour, salt and baking soda. I did increase the salt and baking soda to 3/4 t. hoping it would help the bread to be light, rather than dense like most cornbread seems to be. The bread turned out beautiful, light, a little sweet with a thin crispness around the edges. I checked on it at 23 minutes just to see where it was in the baking process and the pick came out clean so I removed it from the oven and checked it again since the baking time was supposed to be approximately 30 minutes. This cornbread is perfect in every way. I shared half of it with an 84 year old neighbor who said it was the best she had ever had.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We really enjoyed this cornbread recipe.  I have made this recipe many times, and always get great results. To suit our taste, I added 2/3 cup of frozen corn to the mix. Here's a tip you might appreciate: When I buy buttermilk, I always pour 1 cup portions in sandwich bags to freeze for when I need buttermilk. Before, I could never use up my buttermilk, and it always went bad. Now, I finish every carton to the last drop. It thaws out fairly quickly if you put it in a bowl of water.  When thawed, it might look a bit separated, but  just shake it up to incorporate again. Using it in recipes like this or others, hasn't made any difference in the quality or taste of the baked goods.

text:
This recipe is awesome. Moist and tasty cornbread that doesn't fall apart when you slice it. I use a cast iron skillet, start with melting the butter, turn off heat then add buttermilk and eggs and quickly add dry ingredients. Then I pop it in the oven. Always turns out great! However, someone mentioned to me recently that he heats up his iron skillet in the oven first, mixes the ingredients aside then adds to the hot skillet and returns to the oven. I have yet to try this. He says that it makes the edges more crispy.

text:
Very simple yet quite tasty. Lends itself well to tweaks, I made it with only 1/4 cup sugar. The main thing is that it is reasonably moist and not prone to crumbling. By all means fry up some bacon or sausage in a cast iron skillet first, pour the batter into the grease on the stovetop, wait until the edges start to pull back and then pop it into the oven.

You could very easily add some caramelized onion, finely chopped jalapeo, some extra corn meal, and make hush puppies.

I've been making this now for awhile. Very often I use it for large gatherings. I multiply the recipe by 6 and make it in a 16X24 pan. Comes out absolutely amazing.   Last week I served butttered corn the nite before I made the cornbread and had a lot leftover so I pured it and added four cups to my batter for a 16x24  pan.   It was wonderfully moist and had a great texture.   Everyone loved the flavor the corn added to the bread.   I will continue to make this cornbread. It's always a big hit among cornbread lovers and even non cornbread lovers.

text:
Very good, but a bit sweet and cake like.  The recipe fills a 9" cast iron skillet well. I will try it in a 10.25" CI skillet next time for a thinner version.   Half recipe might be a good fit for an 8" or two 6" skillets.  Thanks for the recipe.  It's very good as is, and a good one to adjust or experiment with.  I am thinking of reducing the sugar and adding a few minced jalapenos in the next one.

text:
Search no more for a cornbread recipe! I'd make this a 10 star if I could!  
Sure, you could lessen the sugar, but don't. It's perfect just the way it is! The crumb is just perfect...probably due to the buttermilk. 
I did everything in the same pan I baked it in. Micro'ing, and swirling melted butter up sides of pan to coat it, then mixing the ingredients as stated. While it seemed odd, I promise, it worked great! It DIDNT stick to a 8x8 glass pan. Popped right out. Wasn't dry at all! Next time tripling, and freezing! 
Thanks for sharing this with the world!

text:
I really liked this corn bread! It mixed up very quickly, and was moist and delicious!  It is very forgiving! I had no buttermilk, so I made *clabber milk using whole milk, and it worked great! As I was taking the cornbread to a dinner, I lined my 9" baker with parchment paper, so I could remove it easily and cut it into even servings. I definitely will make it again! 
*Clabber milk- 1 Cup whole milk mixed with 2 teaspoons white vinegar. Let sit until thickened.

text:
I first made this recipe when I was on the cooking committee to serve lunch to about 35 hungry missionaries. They gobbled it up! It is now my favorite corn bread recipe. It comes out moist, buttery and just sweet enough especially good when eating a spicy meal like chili or taco salad. When serving the luncheon I used real buttermilk but at home I didn't have it and used 1 tablespoon of white vinegar with enough milk added to make 1 cup and it worked out fine. This recipe is easy and does not disappoint.

text:
If I could give this recipe 3 more stars I would. Depending on who I'm cooking for, I reduce the amount of sugar. The other thing I do (not that this recipe needs more butter) is place about 3-4 tablespoons of butter to melt in the pan I'll be baking the cornbread in. If you place that pan in the oven until the butter sizzles, it will fry the edges of the cornbread batter. This gives it those crispy fried corners that everyone loves.

text:
First of all, I disagree with the "no true Southerner puts sugar in their cornbread" comment. I am as Southern and as country a cook as you will find. Raised in central Louisiana on a farm by a woman who wasn't afraid to cook anything lol. My momma always put a little sugar in her cornbread and I have had plenty of old Southern cooks who liked it sweet and some who didn't. Why do some folks feel the need to be so condescending? This is a fabulous recipe, as is. As a matter of fact, it is now this family's favorite (including the old ones). Thanks for a great recipe! God bless!!

text:
Oh, my, this was good! I didn't have buttermilk, so I soured some milk with vinegar first. I used an oven-safe pan to melt the butter and after adding the sugar,  I dumped it into a bowl and continued with the recipe. No sooner had I dumped it back into the pan, I decided I wanted corn in it. So I threw in a can of sweet corn. What the heck, right? Maybe it would work. Living dangerously in the kitchen. Anyways, In about 22 minutes it was golden brown, just how I like it. From past experience, I was afraid I'd over cooked it, but it was still very moist.  Wooo hoo, I finally made some decent cornbread!

Forgot to mention, I used Lily white flour, like I use for biscuits. Lily flour is just awesome.

text:
Hello Bethany, thank you so much for sharing your Grandmother's special recipe for cornbread.  I have been trying different cornbread recipes throughout the past year, trying to find one I can make whenever I serve my chilli & my shepherd's pie....they go great together!

 Always check on your baked goods at the first minute marker given. For example, bake 30 to 40 minutes.... you check it at 30 minutes. Everyone's oven varies, altitudes vary, the flour you use  makes a difference in bake time...even the pan you use can make a difference. If it's not completely done, I would suggest continuing to bake in 1 to 2 minute intervals until completely baked.

text:
No, I did NOT make any changes, and yes, I WILL make it again - just as it's published with a slight alteration to the steps of ingredients.  I melted the butter in my mixing bowl (glass) in the microwave, then added the sugar, then added the buttermilk in order to cool the butter/sugar mixture to ensure the egg doesn't "cook" in my slowness, then added the egg, and then followed everything else in the order published by the original author.  We absolutely LOVED it and care not a whit whether or not a "true Southerner" would or would not add sugar - we just like good food and the taste speaks for itself!

text:
I first made this cornbread about 2 weeks ago.  I made a double batch and froze the second batch. I was a little hesitant about freezing, because I usually don't like any type of "bread" product being frozen....seems to make it too dry when it is reheated. Not this recipe! I reheated the frozen batch and it was just as delicious as a fresh batch. Tonight, I'm making 4 batches to freeze...it's seriously that good! Bethany, this is now the ONLY cornbread recipe that I will be making. Thank you!

Excellent! Made with half amount of sugar in recipe because we don't like it too sweet. Also didn't have buttermilk so I added vinegar to a bit less than 1 cup milk and let it sit for a while to curdle before using. Baked in 8 inch round cake pan for 30 mins only. text:
I doubled the recipe except for reduced sugar to 1 cup, and used a 9" x 13" stoneware. Baked at 400 for 30 minutes. Took to a chili potluck and it was a huge hit. It is sweet, and I may reduce sugar more next time. The buttermilk and melted butter add good moisture, unlike many cornbread recipes.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tried this recipe today and used the whole wheat flour. The cornbread had a nice crunch but was most and flavorful. I had all the ingredients except the buttermilk so I did what my mom use to do. I added 1 TBS. of white vinegar into my 1-cup measuring cup, filled it the rest of the way with 1% milk, stirred, and let it sit for 5 minutes while I put the rest of the ingredients together. It worked like a charm and I baked it for 35 minutes and it turned out perfect. My brother had the cornbread with the meal and he even commented how good it tasted. That really made my day because he is a very finicky eater and very difficult to cook for. Believe me...this is a great recipe.

Very good. I made 3 different recipes on one night. This one was the best to my taste, but then I am a "yankee" so the northern (sweet) corn bread was better for me than the souther (no sugar) recipe I made. The kids loved it. Not overly sweet. May make it again but will be looking for a less dense recipe more like the Jiffy corn muffin mix but from scratch. ;)

Tried this last night and loved it.  The few modifications I made was to melt the butter in the microwave, didn't have any buttermilk at home so I put a tablespoon of white vinegar in a cup of milk and let it sit for 5 minutes, and I cut the sugar down to just half a cup. I enjoy the comments and improvements on my recipe.

text:
Amazing cornbread! I followed the recipe as is except for reducing the sugar to 1/2 cup as other reviewers recommended. It was delicious with only a hint of sweetness. Also, used a 9 inch square pan and it was done in 25 minutes. Moist, delicious and a great addition to our Thanksgiving dinner. Next time I would either find an 8 inch pan or if still using the 9 inch, bake it only 20 minutes to ensure that the side pieces were as moist as the center pieces.

text:
aweseome recipe! we've made only a few small changes. 2/3 cup of sugar is way too much. we use 1/2 and it is still sweet and yummy. at 2/3 is was unpleasant to eat, but 1/2 is perfect. also, we use whole wheat pastry flour in place of the white flour, and i brown the butter before mixing the sugar in. in my oven, it's done in 25 minutes--way less the 40 it takes for grandma. :) and good thing! because this has become my little son's favorite food. he has me make it at least twice a week. thank you for the wonderful recipe!

o, and one more thing: instead of buying buttermilk just for this recipe we use 1/2 cup of plain yogurt and 1/2 cup of milk for the liquid. 

thanks again!! love it!!!

text:
Excellent recipe. i substituted brown sugar for white sugar and used corn flour vs corn meal for a smoother texture. but it came out very good.  the true test is when i take it to the office picnic tomorrow...

11/27/2014 - tried it with the cornmeal and it was great, i still used the brown sugar though.  and i used a muffin tin instead of a pan, so for that it took about 15 minutes a pan. check on the brownness and use a toothpick to test doneness.

i'd still give it 5 stars because i don't know of "Southern cornbread" i'm from Maryland, if it tastes good, i'll eat it.

I don't own a cast iron skillet but I almost always use stoneware when baking (Parini) and it gives the cornbread that lovely crust on the sides and bottom.  I love this recipe and I will never use another one. It was effortless to throw together and came out perfectly moist and buttery. text:
This recipe (sugar and all) was a perfect accompaniment to chili.  It had a nice moist crumb and I did not find it excessively sweet,  Being from Canada, I have zero expertise in the characteristics of a "real" Southern cornbread but I take the word of those in the know that this doesn't qualify.  I think anyone looking for more of a "cake" type cornbread would like this one.  I think it could be easily customized by adding cheddar, green chiles and/or corn (for a Tex Mex take) or perhaps berries (for a sweeter variation).  I will definitely make this again and again.

text:
My husband LOVED this cornbread!  I liked the consistency, and the crust/edges had a nice crisp to them.  Although we don't usually eat sweet cornbread (yes, it's a long held southern view that only Yankees put sugar [of any amount] in cornbread), this was a nice accompaniment to our meal.  I will make it again, just be sure to pair it with appropriate foods.  Appreciate the updates from the author, and since it came out exactly as described, I think anyone having serious problems with this is not following the directions.

text:
Awesome! I saw the previous reviews about this being too sweet but followed the recipe exactly. My husband loved it, but I thought it was too sweet. So now, one time he gets it his way and the next I make it with no sugar, and it still turns out wonderful and moist. Also, "southern" cornbread has more cornmeal than flour, and doesn't use eggs, but I prefer this recipe because it is so versatile. I now use this as the basic recipe for so much more...bacon grease in the bottom of the pan (a touch of southern roots), jalapeno and cheddar, tamale pie...so many variations to try. This is definitely a simple, "go to" recipe that I will have in my cookbook as a staple.

text:
I've served this cornbread to some very finicky dinner guests and it's always a hit. I've used Bob's Red Mill cornmeal, medium grind, rather than a finer grind cornmeal and it produces a great texture with a wonderfully light texture, with just a hint of crunch from the coarser cornmeal. I'm now the designated corn bread baker for our holidays meals, thanks to this recipe!

goodbye Jiffy!

This thing is amazing.

I added a can of corn (drained) for some extra texture and corn-ness.
This is literally the first time I ate cornbread without putting any butter on it (or wanting to, anyway)... thought I *might* have to reduce it next time by a tad (it's really, really buttery... which besides its impact on my dress size, is always a good thing).

My wife's large Southern family (Tn & So Car) all use sugar in their cornbread.  Took this survey at last years family reunion.  So saying Southerners don't use sugar just does not hold water. I am a true southerner and I do like my cornbread sweet my grandmother use to sweeten her cornbread with honey and topped it with honeybutter...Now if you like sweet cornbread follow directions if you like it slightly sweet use half the sugar if you are a "true southerner" like plain cornbread don't use the sugar at all...simple.  Now my family likes this cornbread and I melt my butter in a cast iron skillet and then pour my batter in (my grandmother always made it that way) it comes out the pan easy and have that nice buttery taste to it.

None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has been my "go-to" recipe for cornbread. It's not a Southern cornbread! It's a Northern/New England style. The first time I made this, I felt it was a little too sweet. I like to use honey and butter on top of the cornbread. With the amount of sugar listed, it ended up a bit too sweet, so I cut back to 1/4 cup sugar and it's perfect for us. If you don't like sweet cornbread, this isn't the recipe for you. If you like moist, sweet cornbread, then I highly recommend you try this one!

This was easy, use a big skillet and double the recipe for 9x13 rectangular pan. Grease pan with shortening. Comes out 21/2 to 3 inches thick!! Tastes wonderful. Not too sweet but just right! Watch baking time to 20 min and stop after that when edges pull slightly away and are light brown.

text:
This is the best. I don't understand the southern cornbread comments. I can't stand southern cornbread, the sugar from the cornbread ends up in the tea and the pecan pie. The nice crust taste from the cast iron pan is the heat caramelizing the sugar of course. This works with most of the combinations people like; Chile; ham; etc. I wouldn't do the REALLY southern thing of putting it in a glass of milk or buttermilk. The southern style does seem to suit that. Overdry is, most often, overcooked.

3188927
Display Name:
Texasgal_Momma

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1025261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family loves this cornbread!! I usually make these as the recipe states - which is great. The best part (other than the soft, delicious taste) is that I've only had to use one pot to make it in and then of course the cooking dish. This could be avoided though if you have a cast iron skillet, I think. Also, many times I have don't have buttermilk on hand so have to make adjustments. These have been the successful adjustments for no buttermilk: put 1 TB lemon juice in a measuring cup then add milk to the 1 cup marker and let stand for about 5-10 minutes.  Or recently I did not have enough milk !! I measured the milk I did have (about 1/2 cup) and added 1.5 Tsp of lemon and let that curdle for about 7 minutes and then added enough sour cream to make it a measured 1 cup. Then I found more milk (one of my kids left a small cup in the fridge from that morning and decided to throw that in) and then just added a bit more cornmeal in the pot (a heaping cup vs. just a cup pretty much) to make up for the wet/dry proportion. Also, this recipe goes great with red beans & rice!

text:
This is absolutely the BEST cornbread, if'n ya like the sweet kind!! This is the only cornbread I make in my house.  I make this in my huge supersized lodge skillet and make it for 24 servings (we have 6 in our family) and it only lasts 2 days once it's made. I also make it for a breakfast/brunch by scattering whole, fresh blackberries over the top and pushing them down a bit into the batter and then sprinkling some "Sugar in the Raw" all over. It ends up being a great sweet treat for the kids and there's never a crumb left. Enjoy!

text:
Made this for a cookout this weekend.  Never made cornbread before.  Thought this was really easy.  I made a double batch because of the number of people.  I mixed everything in one pot and it was so easy.  I split the recipe into 2 and put canned sweet corn in half to experiment. Both turned out great.  I got rave reviews.  My 8 year old thought it was too sweet though.  I will experiment next time and decrease the sugar a little (we compared it to the cornbread you get at Boston Market and it's way sweeter).  However, I liked it a lot.  I just like to experiment. Because I had made a double batch and only had 1 8inch pan, I put the rest in loaf pans.  Turned out great.  Oh, and they baked perfectly at 30 minutes (both batches, with and without the corn).

text:
Great sweet cornbread. I had to substitute corn flour instead of cornmeal because I could not find cornmeal here in Ukraine. So I just used it instead of adding all purpose flour. Turned out great. I actually found myself liking the texture better. Not as crumbly. Also the recipe temperature in Celsius shows 175 degrees. This is really 345 degrees Fahrenheit. For European bakers you might want to bake this recipe at 190 degrees Celsius. Equal to 374 degrees Fahrenheit. Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
Fabulous corn bread. Use this recipe if you like a moist, dense, sweet corn bread. After making this many, many times, I have made a couple changes that make this corn bread the best I've ever had. I use half honey and half granulated sugar. I also put the baking dish, ungreased, into the oven while it preheats. When it is done preheating, I take the dish out, melt a small amount of butter in the bottom, and then pour the batter into the hot dish. This gives it a fantastic rise in the oven.

country:
None
text:
Perfect sweet cornbread!!!  This is so easy to make why would you buy a premix??  It is moist, sweet, no bitterness, and easy to freeze and take out what's needed!

I printed this recipe several years ago and it is my go-to recipe for cornbread.  I never keep buttermilk on hand but the substitute I use is 1 cup milk plus 1 tablespoon white vinegar, let sit 10 minutes.  I make sure to start with that step so it is ready when I need it.  I use an iron skillet, mix up the batter, and pop the whole thing in the oven.  

A few tips on some variations:
Using a cast iron skillet, preheat to 365 (I have gas) and cook for 25 minutes
For muffins, cook for 20-25 minutes

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my Go To cornbread recipe since coming across it last year. Yes it is sweet but it's heavenly and moist as can be! A couple tips....I never have buttermilk on hand so I decrease the milk to 3/4 cup then stir in enough white vinegar to equal the full cup (about 2 Tbsps). I let this sit and "marinate" while I'm prepping everything (about 10 minutes or so) as it will turn in to some semblance of buttermilk. As for mixing the egg into the hot sugar-butter concoction I usually whisk the egg in a separate bowl then SLOWLY pour it into the skillet stirring briskly as I go. (I've accidentally scrambled my egg once and ruined the whole thing and had to start over). This recipe is a bit labor intensive until you learn the sequence but overall my family and I think it's worth the effort.

text:
I made this for the first time as a counterpoint to another cornbread recipe from this site.  I served both to guests for a chili supper.  Everyone loved this bread.  It is moist and holds together well yet still has a nice crumb.  It rose beautifully - a full 2 inches - and was perfectly done at 30 minutes.  It is a no frills recipe and provides a simple and delicately flavored bread.  It went well with the spicy chili and the next day (still moist and soft) it tasted great with a little smear of honey butter.  It's an easy recipe that comes together quickly and gives you a great return on your time investment.

text:
I made this last night as a side dish to some home made chili...It is deliciously sweet, moist, and rose to perfection. The key is following this recipe exactly..and not making substitutions. Put it in an 8x8 square pan if you like a nice thick piece of cornbread. It is wonderful slathered with butter. I cooked mine for the full 40 minutes. Be sure to grease the pan well with vegetable oil. 

*Note-I have found that milk and vinegar is just NO substitute for good ole buttermilk! Get some! Really! It is so versatile and can be used in many things.

Display Name:
Lana Massaro

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6060737.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
LOVE this recipe! I make it as written. The only thing I do different is I make it in a cast iron skillet. Use either a large skillet or 1/2 of the recipe fits perfectly in a 9 inch skillet. (the original recipe makes a LOT of cornbread) Put the skillet in the oven as you are preheating it. Leave it there for at least 10 min longer to get it good and hot. Right before pouring the mix in, carefully take it out, add 1 T butter and swirl the butter to coat. Add the mix, put it in the oven. The bread will cook much faster than stated on this recipe and you want to take it out just when the center is set so it is not dry. (takes about 20 min) The skillet gives the edges a nice yummy crisp.

text:
UPDATE: MY NEIGHBOR (WHO I SHARED THIS WITH) IS FROM THE DEEP SOUTH. SHE LOVED THIS AND TOLD ME THAT THIS IS EXACTLY HOW CORNBREAD IS MADE IN THE SOUTH. IF YOU ARE LOOKING FOR AN AUTHENTIC CORNBREAD, I GUESS THIS IS IT. :) This was OK... a decent yet basic cornbread recipe. I must confess.... My loyalty goes to bluegirl. Her golden sweet cornbread is the BOMB. Don't get me wrong. This is a fine cornbread. It's just not as sweet as I would have liked it to be (I'm a sucker for sweet cornbread). Because bluegirl's recipe produces a cornbread with a coarse crumb, I decided to try something different this time (I like moist cornbread, but bluegirl's is SOOOO darn good, I can overlook the fact that it isn't). I appreciate the moist, tender texture of this cornbread, but simply put, bluegirl's just tastes better. Thanks anyways, Ms. Weathersby! :-)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So I made a few changes to make the recipe more healthy but it still tasted GREAT. I used half whole wheat and half unbleached white flour. Cut the sugar to 1/2 cup and the butter to 6 tbsp (3/4th of a stick). To make up for it, I added a 1/4 cup of unsweetened apple sauce. Also I didn't have butter milk so I just added a tbsp of apple cider vinegar on another reviewer's suggestion to 1 cup of regular 2% milk. Baked for 35 minutes (30 would probably have been ok too) and it turned out super yummy! Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
I didn't manage to copy down the instructions for the recipe and just mixed the dry ingredients then add the wet ingredients and stir to combine. I only used about 2 tbsp of butter and 1 tbsp of canola oil and melted them in the skillet in the preheating oven. Also only used 1/3 cup sugar and thought it was plenty sweet enough. Can perhaps reduce to 1/4 cup if you don't have a sweet tooth. Used vinegar+milk for buttermilk. Baked it in cast iron skillet. Overall tasty cornbread. Has a nice crust to it which I enjoyed. Done baking in slightly less than 30 mins. Will be using this recipe again for sure!

text:
AMAZING!!!!  These were sweet and just perfect.  I like a particularly sweet cornbread, so I added more sugar.  I also am on a gluten-free diet and had to substitute for that.  I used King Arthur Gluten-free All Purpose flour (same amount) and added a 1/2 tsp of Xanthan Gum.  The cornbread rose nicely and was moist and not crumbly (a typical problem with gluten-free baked goods).  Just perfection!!!  THANK YOU!!  I wasn't sure I'd ever be able to find a good cornbread recipe ever again.  My husband even said it is better than its "gluteny" counterpart.  This will be my staple cornbread recipe from now on.

If you like sweet cornbread, this is for you.  I actually like the level of sweetness.  I am going to play around with the reviewers ideas of cutting down on calories.  The calories are worth the moist, rich taste of this recipe!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I do not know who said sweet cornbread isn't from the south..lol My family came from poor farmers in the south that lived on sweet cornbread and buttermilk. I love this recipe. Very easy and quick. I did mine all in a cast iron skillet. Melted the butter and mixed in sugar. I didn't have buttermilk so I added vinegar to the milk before the baking soda and let it sit while melting butter. I then removed from heat added all ingredients and mixed well.!!! It is a hit at my house, which contains three teenage rednecks that are picky about their cornbread..lol I also want to say I used real stone ground cornmeal. I do not know if that makes a difference to others but it does to us. We are all into simplicity and using "real" foods.Not organic or prepackaged... Just saying:)

text:
I've made this twice now and we love it.  I did make a few changes.  I used 1/4 cup sugar (we don't like sweet cornbread) and the 2nd time I did 1 1/2 sticks of butter instead of the called for 1 stick.  It was much more moist, I'll do that again next time!  I also melted the butter right into a cast iron skillet and added all the ingredients directly into the cast iron and popped it into the oven.  Less mess!

This is a great recipe and it came out great the first time I tried it. I did mix wet ingredients first then dry ingredients. My kids practically inhaled it:)

text:
Just the way I enjoy cornbread - sweet and moist.  And it's really fast to whip up a batch.  I've made it with real buttermilk, but have also used buttermilk substitutes in a pinch (1% milk mixed with 1 3/4 tablespoons of cream of tartar, which didn't sour enough, so I added about 1/8 cup yogurt).  The substitute worked just as well if you don't have buttermilk on hand.

text:
5 star recipe all the way!  I LOVED this.  I have never made home-made cornbread ever, and this was easy easy EASY.  I mixed it all in a cast iron (round) pan, and baked it for 30 minutes.  I inverted the pan to put the round cornbread onto a serving dish, but it stuck to the bottom.  I ran a very thin and pliable spatula underneath, and then tried again - popped right out, not a piece broke. Then I cut into slices (I think this cut into 16ths).  Of course, I had to taste one, and OH MY GOODNESS!  I'll leave you with that!

text:
This is a wonderful recipe, and exactly what I was looking for. I used whole wheat flour, reduced the sugar by half and used RAW sugar.  The regular amount of sugar is not too sweet, but I personally preferred a little less sweet and a little more healthy. The first time I made these I cooked them for 30 min and they were dry, so I made them again and cooked for 18 min and they were much better, could probably go a minute or two shorter even, so I suggest watching them. Great Recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very moist cornbread. I made the cornbread to serve with my meal tonight. These were easy to put together. I followed directions and ingredients to a "T". The only thing I changed was the baking method, which was to make muffins instead of using an 8 inch square baking pan. I poured the batter in each muffin tins that I sprayed with PAM. I baked them up at 375 degrees for 23 minutes. They are a golden yellow color with a nice round top as a muffin should be. The muffins are very moist and tasty. Nothing overpowering at all, only slightly sweet - which I like. I found no need to reduce the sugar amount as others have previously stated in their reviews. I ended up with 14 beautiful muffins. I served them warm along with, "Beef Barely Vegetable Soup," also from this website.

text:
This cornbread is so good!!! We've been using this recipe in my family for a couple of years now, affectionately calling it "corncake," and we LOVE it! It's great exactly as the recipe goes, but you can also tweek it as you like. When I made it today I only use 1/2 cup of sugar, made half of the flour be whole wheat, and subbed in applesauce for the butter (I think I'd only sub applesauce in for half the butter next time). But it's delicious the original way, too, I just like experimenting!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
WOW just WOW!
I wanted to make a "mix in a jar" for cornbread for gift giving, and I saw this and thought I would give it a try.
So I made mine like this,
I mixed all the dry ingredients (using only 1/2 c sugar) and powdered buttermilk. (4 tblsp as directed on the package for the 1 c equilivent)

Then I melted 1 stick of butter added 1 cup water (as per the directions on the powdered buttermilk) and two eggs, just put them on top of the dry ingredients.   Mixed until smooth with a vinyl scraper spoon.  Put into a 8" buttered pan, and baked at 375 for 30 minutes.

PERFECTION!! super moist and I think it will go over great as a gift.  Just mix the dry ingredients and put in jars make sure you add a tag with the recipe and there you go!  I am so excited to give this!  Would make great craft show items too or just bring a few with a baked loaf to a pot luck - your host/hostess will thank you for it!

Thanks for the great recipe!

Just made this exactly as written. I used the same skillet I melted the butter in (mine is pretty huge) and I whisked everything in after. Baked in a 9X9 brownie pan for 30 minutes exactly, although next time I'll check it at 25. I also agree with other people's comments... less sugar for a savory cornbread (had the full amount of sugar with lentil soup.. it was interesting but not bad). Will make again!

This is a truly classic corn bread recipe.  It carries the right balance between dense and fluffy and it's so tasty you'll find yourself going back for more, like it's dessert.  I cut back on the sugar to half a cup, just personal preference.  I also doubled up on the ingredients, still using an 8x8 pan and adding 15-20 minutes to the baking time and the rise was perfect.

text:
I make this at least every 2 weeks. This is the BEST cornbread recipe I have ever made. The only change is that I microwave the butter in my large glass measuring cup (4 cups) and then mix ALL ingreidents right in the measuring cup. It makes it a lot easier and comes out great. If you use one of those brownie pans from Bed, Bath & Beyond or Michaels, with "pre-cut" squares, your cornbread squares would come out PERFECT!

text:
I made this for the second time tonight. It's absolutely perfect.  I "retired" from cooking cornbread because it kept turning out poorly.  I really enjoy it and missied it, especially when I ate chili.  So, in December I scoured the web and read lots of recipe reviews.  This is the one I chose to make and it turned out fantastic -- both times.  I wrote at the top of my recipe: "This is it! The best cornbread -- ever!"  

I rarely write online reviews, but I had to do it for this cornbread.  If someone can come up with something this good other people need to know about it.  

Last, I used Saco Buttermilk blend (powdered buttermilk/sour milk) for the the buttermilk and it was perfectly acceptable.  I prepared it as if it were corn starch -- cold water, whisk, continuous stirring.  

Enjoy!

text:
Don't get me wrong, this recipe worked just fine; I just don't think it's at all deserving of the overwhelming 5-star rating.  I followed the recipe exactly except I substituted 2/3 c plain greek yogurt and 1/3 c milk for the 1 c buttermilk.  Also used wheat flour ILO the all-purpose (as recommended by the author in her own comment).  Cooked for 30 minutes.  It is a little sweeter than I'd like, and pretty dense.  The wheat flour works okay; I'd use it again just for the health benefits, but really it doesn't make the end product "cornbread" like you'd think of...  I'd consider making it again -- probably with a little extra baking soda and maybe AP flour -- but I am still searching for the perfect go-to cornbread recipe.

Display Name:
MrsChmerkovskiy

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is definitely Yankee Cornbread and not Southern Cornbread, so if you're looking for that salty cornbread taste don't even try this recipe.  That being said, this cornbread is delicious!  I melted the butter in the microwave and added into a larger bowl that already had the 2/3 c. sugar in it...no point in melting on the stove top when the microwave works just fine and is less hassle.  I also don't have an 8 in. sq. pan, so I used my loaf pan, and it was fine.  I baked it for about 35-40 minutes and it was perfection.  It has a subtle cornmeal flavor to it, accompanied with the perfect amount of sweetness.  The buttermilk is just the icing on the cake!  If you don't have buttermilk on hand, which I normally don't but I lucked out today, sour some milk yourself.  You can do that by adding white vinegar or lemon juice to the milk.  Let it sit for a couple minutes, and it will sour right up.  I just don't think it would have the same great flavor if you didn't use buttermilk or soured milk.

text:
This was the first time I've made cornbread from scratch.  It was an overwhelming success.  Everyone at the table raved about this recipe.   I followed the original recipe except I couldn't decide if I wanted white or yellow corn meal so I used both.  I used 1/2 c. white corn meal and 1/2 c. stone ground yellow corn meal.  Correction, I just checked the label and I used stone ground white corn meal.  Anyway the mixture of textures added a lot.  This bread was flavorful,, buttery, and just the perfect sweetness.  I also baked it in a preheated cast iron skillet greased with 2 tbsp butter. This is a prefect recipe.

text:
Made this for New Years Eve to go with some black eyed peas, rice and collard greans. Because I dislike the smell of buttermilk, I used a powdered buttermilk substitute from the baking section at my grocery store.  I thought the taste was ok, but my fiance' liked it.  He asked me to make it again for a football party, so I did, using real buttermilk (while I held my nose).  :-)  Everyone luv'd it including me. Very moist with just the right amt. of sweetness and an overall good flavor. I guess by using real buttermilk, that made the difference.  I even drizzled a little melted butter on it after it had baked, so no one even asked for butter to spread on their pieces.  I made a full size aluminum pan of this by quadrupling the recipe and with that much only a few small pieces were leftover.  Many people went back for seconds or even took some home. I had one friend say that it was the best cornbread that he'd ever eaten and couldn't believe I'd made it, let alone from scratch.  Yes, I'm patting myself on the back.  LOL

text:
I doubled the recipe, used 3tbls cider vinegar with the 2 cups milk, added 1 cup heavy grated parm. cheese and 1 small can of chopped green chillies a little more flour and corn-meal to compensate for the wet chillies and a little less sugar. Then cooked in a greased pre-warmed dutch-oven (no lid) for 45min. or so. I could tell when it was done when the cornbread started to come away from the edge of the pan. With all the cheese in there the toothpick trick does not work all that well.  Great recipe, you guys are making me look like a pro!!!

text:
This recipe trumped my grand-mother's recipe.  I did make one slight modification...I cook it in a cast iron skillet and reduce the sugar a to about 1/2 c.  This recipe made me giggle when I first read it.  The first part tells you to work in a skillet and then pour into a baking dish.  I immediately knew this was an OLD recipe and should have been cooked, stove-top, in a cast iron skillet and then transferred into the oven to bake.  It is a light, sweet old-fashioned yummy recipe!  My family loves it so much that I have to double the recipe and make two batches at the same time!!

None
country:
None
text:
You know how you're always looking for just ONE really good recipe for a particular item and then you say you'll stick with it? This is it for cornbread! The recipe is simple and produced great results as followed. If you're using regular all-purpose flour it really only needs 30ish minutes to bake. I think 40 would dry it out.  I didn't even use a sauce pan, but rather melted the butter in the microwave in a large bowl, and then let it cool on the counter a bit before I mixed in the eggs and other ingredients. I also didn't have buttermilk, so instead used regular milk with a splash of apple cider vinegar, and it turned out fine. This base recipe is so good it would be fun to experiment with other additions. Perhaps cheddar, fresh corn, bacon crumbles, jalapenos...

city:

None
country:
None
text:
This is a great cornbread recipe.  I searched the internet for an hour, and most recipes had reviews that said too dry, too bland, etc., or had weird ingredients like goats milk.  This recipe is so easy if you follow Bethany's instructions (in her comment) and do it all in one pot.  I thought for sure the eggs would scramble when I mixed them into the sugar, but they didn't.  Don't let the buttermilk and baking soda sit for very long on the counter because it starts activating and crawls out of its container!  Also an idea to try is to use a roasted cornmeal (like Brinser's Best from Pennsylvania) for a unique flavor.  Thank you Bethany for sharing this recipe!

text:
This was okay but not great. The heat of the pan I melted the butter in caused the eggs to partially cook even though I mixed them in quickly. The only substantial change I made was to bake the cornbread in the pan I used to melt the butter and mix the batter in--adjusting the baking time accordingly. The flavor and texture were just so-so and there was a slightly unpleasant sheen to the top of the cornbread, probably due to partially melting the sugar into the butter. I'm going to stick with my old recipe after all.

text:
Kay's comment is based upon just another Southern cooking myth. The texture, sweetness and flavor of this cornbread was more than I expected and tasted exactly how my honey loves his cornbread.  I have recently returned to cooking from scratch and am now cooking for two.  I prepared this recipe specifically for my honey as he had asked for sweet cornbread.  I used 1.5 tsp of baking powder as I did not have the 1/2 t. of baking soda and 1/3 cup canned milk and 2/3 c. water with 3 T. white vingar as I did not have buttermilk. I baked the cornbread in a prepared 8 inch cast iron skillet for 40 minutes.  I prepared this along with Country Style Green Beans with Red Potatoes and Baby Back Ribs.  We had no room left for dessert tonight.  My honey said that all of the dishes could not have been prepared any better. There is nothing (almost) better than cooking for someone who loves me and appreciates good cooking.
UPDATE: I have made this recipe again and again in a skillet. Tonight I halved the recipe and used a muffin pan for 6. Filled each section 3/4 full and baked for 15 minutes. Made a deep slit in the tops of each and inserted a thick tab of butter. Perfection!

Good recipe. I cut the sugar down to 1/4 cup as I sweeten my corn bread with honey butter and the majority of my household prefers it unsweetened. I've used this substitute for numerous recipes and you can't even taste the difference.

This is wonderful cornbread, even using half the suggested sugar, it worked perfectly. Bethany, thank you  for an outstanding recipe.

text:
My initial feeling was that this is good cornbread, but I didn't notice that it tasted substantially different from any other corn bread I'd tried. On day two, however, I began to appreciate it more. It stays moist, unlike other cornbreads. The buttermilk does add something special. I cut back the sugar by about 1/6 of a cup, and I could have cut it back by more without the bread suffering as a result. My husband insists that I make this again soon. Next time, we're going to try using 1/2 cup of wheat flour in place of some of the white flour.

text:
This is unlike any other cornbread I've ever had! I usually don't have buttermilk on hand, so it was now or never. It was super quick to throw together and cooked up in exactly 30 minutes in my preheated cast iron. I always add butter and honey to my corn bread which was a mistake because this is really sweet by itself! Delicious though, but definitely using slightly less sugar next time. The buttermilk makes it a lot denser than regular corn bread and gives it a great depth of flavor. Adding this one to my recipes!

text:
So yummy! The only thing I change is to bake at 350, but that could just be my oven.  Takes about 25-30 minutes at that temp.  And for those who are confused by the multiple pans, you can always just take a medium sized bowl, melt the butter in it, and start adding ingredients before you dump the finished batter into the greased square pan.   Oh, and I tried reducing the sugar and it's not as good, so I'd recommend keeping it as is.  This is my go to recipe!

I did half country crock/half applesauce instead of butter, sour skim milk instead of buttermilk, and subbed in splenda for half of the sugar. You positively cannot screw this recipe up. Will definitely make again as directed just to see how it turns out.

text:
Work was having a chili day, so I decided to try this recipe and another (plain recipe) from a different site.  Although this was good, I was a little nervous because we had someone bringing Marie Calendar's cornbread (and I REALLY like that one).  Well, ate a piece of Marie Calendar's with the chili....and then a piece of this one....and liked this recipe better!!!   Yes, it is sweet (not too sweet though), so if you are looking for that plain flavor, this is not the recipe for you.  I will keep this recipe in my files and toss out my other one.  I do like sweetened corn bread and will make it again.  I've never made cornbread before, and this recipe was simple.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fabulous! The best corn bread I have ever tasted. It has just the right amount of sweetness and it was very moist. The only thing I did different was in the mixing process. I pre-whisked the eggs in a bowl before adding to the butter sugar mixture in the skillet. Although I removed the skillet from the heat before stirring in the sugar, as the recipe stated, and stirring the eggs in as quickly as possible, the eggs seemed to start cooking (I saw a few small bits of cooked egg in the mixture) so I immediately added the buttermilk mixture to cool it down. I then added the wet ingredients from the skillet to the bowl of pre-measured and mixed dry ingredients. I baked in an eight inch round pan vs square for the same amount of time. Came out perfect!

text:
wow..i am still laughing at how ridiculously foolproof this recipe is. Being the health nut that i am, i decided to use canola oil rather than butter. Thing is, i overheated the oil, so when i added the sugar, it crystallized. I figured that it was because the oil was too hot. not wanting to add the egg immediately, i waited a few minutes. however, when i added the egg, the oil/sugar was still too hot. in essence, i scrambled the egg. since i had a whisk in my hand, i quickly whisked the  mixture. it looked rather disgusting at this point, but i was just like whatever and put the rest of the ingredients in. I baked it as instructed and expected a hard, repulsive tasting brick, but omg..it turned out perfectly. there were no egg lumps or whatnot. the cornbread was soft and moist and the crust was so wonderful. i am definitely going to use this recipe again (using my canola oil =) (but i'll try not to scramble the egg or fry the sugar) lol i'm still laughing at myself.

text:
This cornbread was pretty good but not a 5 star for me because it was a little too sweet.  I made it exactly as stated in the recipe except that I used Egg Beaters for the eggs.  I've never used them before but supposedly they can be used in place of eggs with no noticeable difference.  I don't see how they would have affected the sweetness anyway.  If I decide to try this recipe again, I will reduce the sugar a little...maybe to 1/2 cup...and use real eggs.

Incredible cornbread!  My family likes a sweeter cornbread (like the Jiffy box mix) and they LOVE this.  I don't always have buttermilk on hand so I soured my milk by adding a tablespoon of vinegar to a cup of milk and letting it sit for a few minutes.  I have tripled this recipe and it just fit into a 9" x 13" pan.  When doing this I had to increase the baking time just a bit.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
First, this is a very tasty cornbread.  It has a slightly sweet flavor and is very moist.  I melted the butter, mixed all the ingredients, and baked the cornbread in my old well-seasoned 12 cast-iron skillet and it came out fantastic.  I did mix the flour, cornmeal and salt in a separate bowl but everything else I mixed/melted in the cast iron skillet.  It took 30 minutes to bake and was wonderful.  I allowed it to cool on a wire rack for 10 minutes after baking.  Running a knife around the inside edge and then flipping the skillet the cornbread came out of the skillet perfectly.  Not like my grandmothers cornbread and needed a huge wad a butter just to be able to swallow it was so dry.  Definitely a keeper.

This is amazing cornbread - I almost ate a whole pan by myself. The annoying ingredient is buttermilk, which I often don't have on hand, but it's worth it. I tried a recipe on the back of a cornmeal box and it was not good at all compared to this.

text:
Upon reading most top-rated reviews; I have decided to try this recipe only with the following minor tweaks: -    * Used 1/2C All Purpose Flour and 1/2C Wholemeal Flour.  * Mixed 2 TBSP of Cider Vinegar and filled my milk up to a cup; like most people.  * Whisked the dry ingredients, set aside; then followed by wet ones and finally combined both.    My cornbread came out perfect after 35 min of baking for 375 degrees! NO HARD WORK AT ALL IN MAKING THIS WONDERFUL BREAD!!! It is not overly sweet but moist from within.     I really regretted of not doubling the recipe as advised by the recipe submitter coz after 2 hours cooling, I only had a piece left! No wonder this recipe has got raves from most folks...

text:
I have thrown away 2 batches of cornbread using other recipes.  Im glad I didn't give up. This one is a keeper.  It just came out perfect.  I thought I would be able to taste the buttermilk in the finish product, but you can't.  I made these in a cupcake pan.  I mixed 3/4 of the butter into the batter.  Use the remain 1/4 to grease the cupcake pan.  Only took 22min to bake at high altitude (5000 ft).  I pulled them out as soon as the toothpick came out clean.  Edges were golden brown and crunchy.  Moist inside, Not too dense and not overly sweet for me.  Just perfect.   Oh yeah, full recipe makes 14 cupcakes.  Fill each 2/3 full.

Excellent cornbread recipe!  The best part of this recipe is that the cornbread is sweet and moist (even after it cools).  I made it exactly as stated but doubled the recipe (used two large catering bake pans). Put both in the oven and only cooked it for 40 minutes max.  Keep an eye on it.  Don't want the sides to burn.  I used an electric beater to blend it well.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this as directed with a couple exceptions.  I used my cast iron pan and let the batter less the salt and flour set while the oven/pan were preheating.  I melted some lard (yes lard, its great for pie crusts) in the pan then added the batter. Also I melted the butter in a glass bowl in the microwave and then added remaining ingredients as called for in the bowl, instead of using skillet on stove top and mixing in skillet. The end result is a super yummy bread that is moist and well balanced, just enough sweetness.  This is a more NE style corn bread, not southern.  But don't let that stop you, its easy and great with BBQ, chili, breakfast, just about anything.

text:
My advice, "Double it!" This is a recipe the kids will love! I doubled the batch, made one bread a bit smaller than the second and oh my, how beautiful was the larger (i.e. higher) one! The best part was the taste! Phenomenal! I like this recipe with or without the sugar depending on my mood. If you like yours sweet, go all the way with the sugar. If you don't like sweet cornbread, leave it out - you can't go wrong. Awesome either way! Funny story...only had grits last night and no cornmeal. Put it through the coffee grinder, substituted and out came the most delicious cornbread and no one had the slightest idea. I live in Spain where we make do with what we have. Delicious! I will look no further. I have found the perfect cornbread recipe! THANKS!

What an amazing recipe! It's not dry, it's sweet and so tasty! I melted the butter in a cast iron pan, then added the sugar and eggs.  I mixed the rest of the ingredients in a bowl then mixed everything together - right in the pa - then placed it in the over.  PERFECTION!  I should also add that I threw in a handful of frozen corn and used medium coarse corn meal which gave it a nice texture. A keeper.

text:
Perfect - hands down the best cornbread recipe of many I've tried. It is incredibly moist and just sweet enough without tasting like cake. I will never need to try another recipe again. Although I hate it when reviewers include their substitutions, I had to substitute "fake" buttermilk (1 tablespoon vinegar + 1 cup regular milk) and it worked like a charm. DON'T skip the step where you cream the sugar, butter, and eggs together before adding other ingredients, and don't overmix when you add the dry ingredients.

My husband went insane over this...he was still shoveling it in his mouth as he asked when I'd make it again! Since I didn't have buttermilk I substituted 1 tbsp vinegar for 1 tbsp of the milk and it worked just fine. It only needed 25 minutes in my oven. Delicious! Thank you!

text:
This is a very good cornbread recipe. I replaced 1/2 of the white flour with whole wheat, and it was still very good. I cooked mine in a greased, heated cast iron pan--if I hadn't done that I doubt I would have used any whole wheat flour though. The added grease from the pan counteracted the extra dryness from the whole wheat. I also reduced the sugar to 1/2 cup--personal preference, I wanted my cornbread to be good with chili today, and good with honey for breakfast tomorrow!

text:
This was my first time making cornbread and this is a great recipe. I followed it exactly and had no problems. I did have to make my own buttermilk by adding 1 tbsp of lemon juice to 1 cup of milk and leaving it for 5 minutes. I made them into muffins for a bbq and just reduced the time to 17 minutes. And incase you're wondering, 1/4 pound of butter = 1/2 cup or one block. Enjoy!

text:
This is an excellent cornbread recipe! As recommended, I mixed all of the ingredients together in the skillet and then poured the batter directly into the pan. I also added a small can of sweet creamed corn to the mixture at the very end. This made the bread incredibly moist and very dense... almost like a cornbread pudding! Serve it with butter and it's absolutely delicious! Thank you for sharing your recipe. This one will be tagged as a family favorite!

I used this for the cornbread on the Cheap and Easy Casserole recipe on this site.  Very yummy.  Don't have buttermilk?  No problem, put a tablespoon of vinegar into 1 cup of milk and let sit for 10 minutes.  Voila buttermilk substitute!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
We never have a reason to keep buttermilk in our house, so we create our own!  In a 1 cup measuring cup, add 1tb lemon juice and fill the remainder of the cup with regular milk.  Let it stand for about 5 minutes and VOILA! Buttermilk!  This is very helpful since we are ADDICTED to this cornbread!  The best we've ever had--it always comes out light and fluffy!  Thank you for submitting this recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok so I made my change to it to cut out the fat and cut down on the calories...these were delicious! I just took a can of corn, measured out 1/2 C and put in my food processor; processed until it was fairly smooth (adding water from can as needed). Just replaced the butter with the pureed corn and used whole wheat flour instead of white flour, used 1 egg instead of 2. I also added the rest of the can at the end and folded in. I made in cupcake tins. Each muffin is only 140 calories (12 muffins), 1.5g fat, and 2.33g fiber, 4g protein, .5g sat fat.

text:
I made this recipe the other day and it was so good that we couldn't stop talking about it.  So I decided to make it again last night but didn't have any cornmeal left.  Very disappointed.  So I decided to use semolina (ground durum wheat)it looks similar to cornmeal but it doesn't have the same taste.  Went ahead and made it and it was fantastic.  The only change I made was to use honey instead of white sugar.  Since it tastes so buttery I felt that the honey would add another dimension to the recipe.  It was great.  If I could give it ten stars I would.  I will buy more cornmeal today.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/109.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious cornbread!  I had to make a few changes, because of what I had.  I didn't use buttermilk, because I didn't have any.  So I did the buttermilk substitute of milk/lemon juice (for every one cup of milk, use about two tablespoons less of milk and mix in two tablespoons of lemon juice instead).  Let it sit for a few minutes while it foamed and then poured it in.  Also, the company I was having over who would delight in this dish, wanted creamed corn in it, so without changing any ingredients around, I simply poured in a can of creamed corn and let it cook longer until it was set.  My company loved it and so did we!  Thank you for such a great recipe!  It's a keeper!  *I made this cornbread with Chili Rick's (from this site) and it was delicious together.*

text:
We really enjoyed this, and make it often!  Over time, I've made a few changes - sauteed about 1/2c corn in butter along with sliced jalopenos to taste and added those to the batter.  Reduced sugar to taste.  Finally, I preheated my skillet and melted butter on the bottom so that it sizzled when I poured the batter in - it gave a nice crispy crust on the top and bottom.  Thanks for the great recipe.

text:
This is my first attempt at making cornbread.  I was a little skeptical but needed a quick side dish to accompany the dinner I was making.  Much to my surprise, this cornbread is delicious!  It is moist and plenty flavorful.  I followed the recipe exactly.  I didn't have buttermilk - but I made my own.  Put 1 tablespoon white vinegar in a 1 cup measuring cup.  Then add enough milk to make 1 cup.  Let it sit for 5 minutes, and then use it!

text:
Amazing! We love the sweetness, its a great with a spicy chili.

Due to Egg allergies, I substitute the eggs for 2Tbs Ground Flax and 6Tbs water (simmered for 5 mins to give it a egg white consistnacy)

Due to Milk allergies, I use 1Cup homemade frozen corn making sure to get alot of the yummy corn liquids. (If I find the batter too stiff, I'll add some rice milk to get it to the right consistancy)

Turns out fabulous! As its Hubby and Kid approved, it will remail in my recipe repitoire!!

text:
I made a trial batch before Thanksgiving to try it out and thought it tasted too "cake-like". So for the real thing, I used 1.5 cups of cornmeal and .5 cups of flour. This gave a better, more corny taste. I also tossed in about a 1/2 cup of canned corn (not creamed). Don't worry. The corn will become really soft and disappear into the bread.

I grew up with my mom making sweet cornbread out of a box.  This is so much better and so easy to make.  I do bake it in a cast iron skillet (because that is the only way to make cornbread).  I also use a milk/vinegar substitute if I don't have buttermilk on hand.  Usually I just put a tablespoon of white vinegar in the bottom of a liquid measure cup and then fill it the rest of the way with the milk.  Delicious.  I have already made it half a dozen times in 2 months.

text:
This is an excellent, reliable cornbread that's moist, light and slightly sweet. (Actually, I reduce the sugar to 2 Tb, otherwise it's sweeter than I care for a savory cornbread to be.)

I use sour milk instead of buttermilk -- 1 Tb. lemon juice to the milk called for in the recipe, and I let it sit while I mix the dry ingredients.

text:
I made this for lunch today and the whole family really enjoyed it!  However I made a few healthy modifications: I replaced the butter with 1/2 cup canola oil, I used only 1/2 cup sugar (and that was plenty!), and instead of buttermilk I used 1 cup milk, of which I replaced two tablespoons with lemon juice.  This was the simplest recipe ever and it tasted heavenly - plus it was beautiful to look at, all golden and perfect!  And the outside was so crispy and sweet!  I'm definitely going to use this recipe very often.

text:
As a southerner, I have to say that this falls short of good cornbread... but as a cornbread cake it's not too bad. We actually make a similar recipe at work and add blueberries to it. It sells well this way, but we've  had some people complain about our labeling the plain version "cornbread."  In the south cornbread is never sweet but rather dense and moist with a deep corn flavor. We use only white cornmeal and never add sugar.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I reduced the flour to 1/2 cup and used 1 cup medium grind cornmeal and 1/2 cup finely ground corn flour as I like a slightly more dense, textured bread. I also didn't have enough butter for baking and for slathering, so I used a mixture of light olive oil and vegetable oil instead, and added a bit of extra salt to make up for flavor, and it turned out wonderfully.

I also soaked the corn meal in buttermilk for about a half hour before mixing the ingredients in baking - I find it helps with the coarser grind, makes things a little moister. 

This turned out dense, moist and not too sweet. Next time, I'll probably cut back on the sugar and perhaps substitute a little honey

text:
This recipe is INSANE!! It's quite sweet and rather cake-like but was the perfect compliment to smoked bbq ribs and baked beans. I made it at the cottage for my husband's family reunion and there wasn't a piece left. It was baked in a cast iron skillet (preheat skillet in oven, add 1-2 tbsp oil or butter, allow to melt, swirl pan to coat bottom, pour in cornbread batter and return to oven, cooking for 25-30 minutes or so)... it produced beautiful crust. Also added 1 can (drained) of corn kernels. Excellent, excellent, excellent. My years long quest to find the perfect cornbread is now over!
