text:
This was good~ I took some of the other suggestions & subbed in skim milk+1 tablespoon of apple cider vinegar for the buttermilk/ 1/2 cup of whole wheat flour for the white flour (which did alter the color of the cornbread a bit) & reduced the sugar to 1/2 cup b/c I'm trying to cut back on sugar (but this does make it less sweet than maybe what you would get in a restaurant) ... i was worried when I mixed in the eggs & saw bits of it "cooking" even though the heat was off. But it was fine once it baked - it still rose pretty well & i didn't notice any "egginess" to the cornbread ... this does make a more cake-like cornbread ... so for those who prefer a crumblier/rustic texture should look for another recipe ...

I really don't take the time to rate things very often on this site unless I think they are phenomenal. 

This morning I decided to make my boyfriend breakfast and thought cornbread would really complete the meal. This knocked his socks off. He LOVED it. Ate almost the whole thing. 

I did make a few changes though. It came out great! At the end I poured a bit of melted earth balance over the top.

text:
If I could give it 6+ stars, I would. This was AWESOME!! I have been searching for a sweet, moist cornbread for years! I like my cornbread on the sweet side, so it was perfect. Hey, if you don't like it sweet, use less sugar to what you like. Perfectly moist also. I guess I just don't see how it could be dry??? Mine was cooked perfectly  in an 8x8" glass Pyrex dish, in a gas oven for 33 minutes. They ONLY thing I added extra was 1/2 a cup of sweet corn (well, because I like my cornbread that way and it wasn't going to alter it much). You have to take the pan off the heat and let the butter/sugar cool off a bit before you add your eggs, like many reviewers say, but I already knew that. Heat+eggs=cooked eggs.... not good.

I will make an extra batch dairy-free next time for my 2 & 3 yr old who can not have dairy. I didn't notice the review on making it dairy-free until after I had already baked mine.
We made Cajun pork chops, green Italian salad (family recipe) and grilled peaches with it tonight, but I think I would love it with chili or some nice pulled pork BBQ! YUMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMM!

userID:
549941
Display Name:
Linda Brewer
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
96

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2438592.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
THE PERFECT SWEET CORNBREAD. VERY CLOSE TO JIFFY BUT WITH MUCH CRISPIER CRUST BECAUSE OF THE AMOUNT OF BUTTER. DEFINITELY NOT A DIET RECIPE BUT EVEN HAVING TO EAT A SMALL PIECE MADE IT WORTH MAKING! I DID TAKE THE LIBERTY OF MAKING A FEW CHANGES. I WILL SHARE THEM AS IT MADE IT EASIER AND QUICKER FOR ME.. MAYBE YOU WILL AGREE!

use self rising flour and self rising cornmeal.. both White Lilly brand. omit the soda and salt.
melt butter in skillet on top of stove (mine is gas so i didn't have to remove from heat... only turned it off)when melted remove from heat and add sugar (this is as sweet as jiffy, for more cornbread-like, i would decrease to 1/2 cup or even 1/4. for more cake like increase to a full cup!) when sugar and melted butter are very mixed, QUICKLY QUICKLY  whisk in eggs... careful, they will start to cook, it's okay if you see some tiny strands of white that look like they are cooking... keep whisking (with WHISK). i ADDED CORNMEAL AND FLOUR RIGHT INTO MY SKILLET AND SLIPPED THE WHOLE THING RIGHT INTO MY PREHEATED OVEN!

my skillet was about 9" round and it almost over cooked at 35 minutes... start watching at 25 minutes. it varies according to our individual oven settings. hope this helps! and thanks to whoever created this great recipe!

text:
I tried this today and followed the recipe exactly. I would decrease the sugar by half next time. The texture was great and it held together well. I think the bread may have had such a strong after taste because the butter and sugar kind of settle in the bottom of the pan by preheating it. I think next time I will try mixing the ingredients first and then pouring them into the pan. I will grease the pan first with Pam or a small amount of butter.

06/08 update: I cut the sugar to 1/3 cup. I melt the butter in a glass dish and add liquid ingredients. I put the dry ingredients into the wet and mix well. I have used milk with 1 TAB of vinegar when I do not have buttermilk. I have cooked the mixture in a greased cast iron skillet, both preheated and cold. Either way it turned out great. I lvoe this recipe.

text:
Great recipe! I do believe the recipe was a little too sweet, especially once I started eating it with chili. So I'd cut that down to 1/2 a cup of white sugar.

If you want to make it more healthy: I used whole wheat flour, halved the butter and substituted somewhere between 1/4 and 1/3 cup of honey and a little extra milk. I won't say it's as good as the original, but it's still pretty awesome. :)

text:
Seriously great cornbread. I always make my Grandma's recipe and she is the best cook and baker I know. This one called for sugar so I decided to give it a try as a change of pace. I am glad I did. I did cut the sugar to 1/3 cup after reading the other reviews. I have a very large cast iron skillet so I melted the butter in the skillet in the preheated oven, mixed everything else together in a separate bowl and poured it all on top of the melted butter in the hot skillet before baking. The result was a very buttery, slightly crispy edged cornbread that went very well with chili. It is also very good reheated. Thank you for the recipe!

country:
None
text:
This is a very good and solid recipe.  I won't repeat a lot of what others have said but would like to offer a few suggestions.  View the amount of sugar as negotiable based on your personal tastes; I've made this recipe twice, once with the 2/3 c. sugar (too sweet for me), and once with just 1/4 c. sugar (not enough sweetness), so my personal "sweet spot" is somewhere in between.  An additional 1/2 cup of liquid is a good idea for this recipe if you're so inclined.  And I believe others have mentioned decreasing the amount of flour in respect to the amount of cornmeal which will produce a beautiful yellow color.

Wow, what a great recipe. It's a lot like Boston Market's cornbread. Crisp on the outside but soft and tender on the inside.

This recipe made 12 regular-size muffins. I baked them at the normal temp for about 20 minutes. (I didn't time them exactly; just took them out when they sprang back to my touch.)

I'll be making these a lot. Thanks for a great recipe.

This was my first time making cornbread from scratch, and is it ever addicting!  I made the recipe exactly as it's written (except I substituted 1 c. skim milk + 1 Tbsp. cider vinegar for the buttermilk), and even with an oven that doesn't work well, it came out perfectly.  I'll make this every time I make chili from now on, although next time I'll try it out with less butter (just to be healthier, not because it's greasy).

Ok, I tried making your recipe this weekend, and it went TOTALLY wrong!!! It wasn't your fault nor mines, I mean I followed your instructions word for word, but I figured out what went wrong today, you cannot chage the serving amounts, at least not on baking recipes.  If there is a baking recipe for 9 servings, like yours is, you need to leave it like that, b/c I changed it to 4 servings and it required ridiculous things.  i.e. 7/8 egg!!! what is that...so I'm going to try your recipe again tonight. I'll let you know what the fam says!!

text:
Everybody loved this cornbread at home!!! Just be sure to follow the recipe just as it is, because the first time I made it, I forgot to mix the baking soda with the buttermilk, and just added it in with the rest of the dry ingredients, and the cornbread came out a little dry and did not rise evenly. But the second time I baked it I followed the recipe completly, and it came out wonderfully moist and very tasty; not too sweet (I ate it with my ribs and pork n' beans) and not too salty (my dad ate it for dessert with a cup of coffee). It was just right.

text:
The is good old-fashioned cornbread, the way I remember it from my childhood. I have grown so accustomed to mixes that I forgot what "real" cornbread tastes like. I used less butter, and used only 1/4 cup sugar. Next time I might add a bit more buttermilk; the finished product was a tiny bit crumbly, probably from using less butter. I made it in a cast iron skillet and it was delicious. Bethany thank you for sharing.

I'm just starting to cook and was worried about the outcome.  But I am pleased with this recipe.  It tastes very similar to my mothers.  But I was stranded at home since my car is in the shop so I didn't have buttermilk.  I substituted with 1 cup milk and 1 3/4 tablespoons cream of tartar. If the cook time was a bit less, I think things would have turned out better.

text:
Ive made this several times now and tonight was the best yet. Instead of buttermilk I use one cup milk with two tablespoons distilled white vinegar, let it sit for several minutes. I also use a half cup of sugar instead of two thirds. I use my iron skillet to melt the butter for the mix, then stick the pan in the preheated oven a few minutes before Im ready to pour the batter so its hot (but not smoking).

text:
I used Bob's Red Mill Organic 1-for-1 gluten-free flour with good results. I actually made this directly in a cast-iron skillet, hot on the stove, melted the fat (mixed beef and chicken fat instead of butter), dumped it into the batter, mixed well, then poured right back into the skillet and popped it into a 375 oven. Was done in around 25 minutes and went over very well. Thanks!

text:
I need ten stars for this!  Have been making for a year exactly as written and it is the best recipe for corn bread!  You MUST use buttermilk (freeze the extra in one cup sizes and pop into a zip lock for later then just defrost).  For the 8x8 pan, 30 minutes is just right but check with toothpick as all ovens can vary.  Thank you Bethany and bless your grandmother!
PS, the one pot is genius..just make sure it is big enough.

text:
This recipe, unaltered,  is the best I have tasted. 
I had company of 60, 70 and 80 yr old when I served it for the 1st time.  All raved about it. 
All three people usually put loads of butter on other cornbread and one always put maple syrup on cornbread.    Amazing to me was that no one put any butter  or syrup on this cornbread.    I read a lot of reviews and decided not to modify the recipe.  I am glad I did...it was perfect. Moist and buttery but not like a cake.  Cooked in a hot iron skillet for 35 minutes---directions say 30-40 minutes.  Was perfect !
 There is a reason this recipe is 5K+ 5 stars.

text:
I am not a cornbread lover. They are so often dry, crumbly, and sometimes gritty. I've even had ones that stick to the roof of your mouth. I hate that! But this recipe is delicious! I've had it multiple times now, and it's a definite favorite among friends too. Very tasty and moist. It's got great consistency and isn't crumbly, but just the right density. You don't even need to douse it in chili or honey! It's perfect as is.

text:
I cannot say enough good things about this recipe. not too sweet, not too oily or sticky. it's perfect! I used to buy cornbread mix at the store, but moving to different parts of the country, it's hard to find what I consider to be good in all places. thank God for Grandma's Sour Cream Cornbread recipe. I make it as a side dish for black-eyed peas, Chili, Split-Pea soup, Beef Stew, etc. you will not be sorry! As a help, if you don't have buttermilk, add a Tbl of apple cider vinegar or white vinegar to your cup of milk. Enjoy!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We make this cornbread every Saturday morning. I usually implement substitutions found in other reviews. For instance, I usually sour whole milk with vinegar, instead of buttermilk, just because we have the ingredients on hand and are a small family that struggles to use up a whole jug of whole milk before it expires. I also always substitute whole wheat flour for all purpose flour just for fiber and nutrition. Have never received a complaint. On rarer occasions I substitute other natural, lower calorie sweetners for sugar. Regarding process, I just mix everything in my Kitchen Aid mixer and pour it into a greased 8 inch pan. A lot of the 1 star reviews suggest this recipe is too dry. They probably need to start checking for doneness earlier, maybe 25 minutes instead of 30, and check it every 5. Enjoy!

text:
Mine turned out dense. Almost more custard-like than bread-like.

Part of the issue was my dough was too wet. Next time I would add more cornmeal or flour to make it firmer.

The othe probelem was this recipe needs more levening. When I read the recipe it seemed odd how little there was compared to every other cornbread recipe I like. I decided to trust the reviews and made it anyway. Big mistake. 

If I made this again I would add a 1 tsp of baking powder and reduce the sugar to 1/2 cup.

Doubled recipe and used Splenda for a potluck.

Also used the Instant Pot for the prep.  Melted butter on low Saut till half melted and cancelled program.  Took inner pot out after the butter finished melting.  Added a little of the buttermilk / baking soda mixture to the butter/sugar mixture to cool it down to avoid cooking the egg.  Worked perfectly, and the eggs blended together fine.  Added the rest of the ingredients in order and the depth of the inner pot handled the doubled recipe perfectly.  Poured it all into the prepared baking dish.  Easy peasy!  Can't wait to try the first bite of the baked cornbread.  The batter was sure tasty!  LOL

text:
For those reviewers that dismiss this cornbread as not being "real" Southern cornbread; you're right!  This is (sweet) cornbread, and bears little resemblance to the very good, but unsweet Southern version.  If that's what you're looking for, this is NOT the recipe for you.  I grew up with sweet cornbread, and this is fantastic!! Moist, sweet, a good crumb......just about perfect.  I even cut a piece for myself and eat it in the morning with a cup of coffee.......it's just delicious!

country:
None
text:
Thank you for this recipe, made it before, and will be making it again tonight with a couple tweaks, cutting the sugar in half, and adding some actual corn. I prefer a recipe with butter, instead of oil, and the extra egg ensures this bread will be nice and moist, unless they don't read the instructions and cook it for that 40 minutes lol

And a tip for those I see in their photos have overdone the bottoms of the cornbread, use a cast iron or other heavy bottomed pan, or, at the same time you are putting the pan in (not before then, you want it room temp), put a cookie sheet in under the pan. It'll make it take longer for the pan to heat up, preventing the bottom from cooking faster than the rest of the bread.

Marie Wilson Conner

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3237594.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Works with gluten-free flour! I've made this several times, with changes based on the ingredients I had. It seems to work  no matter what I do to it. Some of my family can't eat gluten, so I've always used gf flour. I've used Bob's 1 to 1, and a mix I made myself with corn starch, millet, and sorghum. Both work. I grew up eating unsweetened cornbread, so I have tried this recipe with different amounts of sugar. I've come to the conclusion that you can just sweeten it to taste. I've used the full amount, half, a quarter, and an eighth. They all work. I've used granulated sugar, light brown sugar, and dark brown sugar. No problems with any of those. I've also used regular milk and buttermilk. Obviously, the taste changes based on what changes you make to the recipe, but nothing I've tried has turned out bad. It's a reliable, flexible recipe.

country:

text:
This was AWESOME!  Reminds me of my mothers Johnny Cake.  I live in the south but grew up in Maine and do not care for the dry/crumbly cornbread around here.  It is great as is, but I think next time I will cut the sugar back some so we can eat it how we are use to...which is drizzled with or dipped into molasses. Cooking time for me was 24 minutes...all ovens are different , altitudes very, and all pans are different.  Cooking in a cast iron skillet, dark metal pan, light metal pan, glass pan, ceramic/pottery pan etc all require different cooking times. For newer bakers, with any  first time baking of a new recipe ...set your timer for much less time than the recipe requires and check.

text:
Yall this is so good.. I dont change a thing about what goes into this recipe (except for the use of a milk and vinegar buttermilk). Ive tweaked the instructions a little bit after some experience making it (not that I had issues before) just to make it a little easier to work with. As for the dryness some have experienced, bake it for 30 minutes and check it from there. Ive never had a dry bread. I LOVE the sweetness. Maybe its because Im from the middle of Illinois, but this is not a southern version by any stretch and Im 100% alright with that. This immediately became my favorite cornbread recipe ever and it is the only one I ever use. Thanks to it, my husband will eat cornbread again and my kids it eat, period. Cant ask for more than that!

text:
This cornbread is amazing! I don't like sweet cornbread so I used 1/5 cup of sugar. I also didn't have any buttermilk so I used 1 cup of milk with about 1 or 2 tablespoons of vinegar added to make sour milk. I cooked the batter in a preheated cast iron skillet that I had melted butter and a bit of bacon fat into while the oven preheated. It cooked in 30 minutes exactly and came out beautifully golden brown. The bread is fluffy and light, yet substantial. This will definitely be my go-to cornbread recipe, and I can see myself adding corn and green onions to it in the future.

UPDATE: I tried it with only  cup of sugar and still found it too sweet for me. I'm now in the no-sugar camp, and have been trying other variations (and recipes). But thanks, Bethany, for getting me started!

text:
Delicious! This cornbread was a hit with my family. It has the perfect amount of sweetness, great texture, and a beautiful crust. I didnt have buttermilk on hand so I added one Tablespoon of white vinegar to a cup of whole milk and made my own. Also, I used a cast iron skillet with a scant quarter cup of melted bacon grease swirled around inside it (and I had it screaming hot from melting the grease in the skillet in the oven) before I added the cornbread batter. That makes a wonderful crust on the bread. I will definitely use this recipe again.

text:
This is delicious cornbread and was a favourite at our bbq. I doubled the recipe and it was not dry at all. It is a little sweet but not overly. I melted the butter and mixed all the ingredients in a stainless saucepan, and while doing that I let my cast iron pan warm up in the oven (melting a tbsp of butter to grease the pan). I poured the mixture into the hot cast iron pan and it cooked in around 32 minutes with a nice crisp buttery crust. I will be making this again.

text:
Awesome recipe as given. Loved it. I made it in an 8x8 pan and it turned out great.  I didn't have buttermilk so I made my own sour milk with just a tad shy of 1c milk and 1Tbl white vinegar.  The  mix turned out easy to do. I f ollowed the author's directions and just made it in the bowl i melted the butter in. Poured it into an 8x8 pan. 

Yes it's sweet. It's supposed to be that's the recipe. If you don't want it as sweet cut back the sugar. As it is it worked out great with a super spicy chili I made. The sweet cornbread cut the heat and it was absolutely delicious. 

HIghly recommend this recipe: Note:I did only bake for 25 minutes. It was done by then and was perfect.

text:
We need to be gluten-free so I used King Arthur measure-to-measure in place of wheat flour. I followed others and mixed it all up in my cast iron skillet and then popped it in the oven. Absolutely delicious! The only change I will make the next time is to add a little more buttermilk. It was slightly dry, but I think that is a function of the gluten-free flour. Cooking in the skillet made it nice and crispy on the outside and only one pan to clean!

I like trying recipes as-written first before I make any changes, and I won't be making any changes to this one.  Even 2nd and 3rd day leftovers were moist, and the only reason we had any left by day 3 was because I made 4 batches of it at once.  Glad I did! In my opinion, this is the perfect cornbread, and I'll be definitely using it often.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Recipe is delicious as is! Quite balanced in flavour. Absolutely best made in a cast iron skillet,  though have made in muffin cups when necessary. Cut muffins into cubes & leave out to dry for up to 2 days for an incredible corn-bread stuffing. (Place all butter in skillet, heat in oven while prepping bread, mix all dry ingredients with fork, drizzle melted butter on dry ingredients,  mix thoroughly with fork, then add wet ingredients.)

For a sweeter bread, add 2 - 3 more TBS sugar.

For a delicious variation, add 1/2-1 can no-salt-added sweet corn (drained) or 1/2 -1 can cream corn to taste.

Recipe is delicious as is! Quite balanced in flavour. Absolutely best made in a cast iron skillet,  though have made in muffin cups when necessary. Cut muffins into cubes & leave out to dry for up to 2 days for an incredible corn-bread stuffing. (Place all butter in skillet, heat in oven while prepping bread, mix all dry ingredients with fork, drizzle melted butter on dry ingredients,  mix thoroughly with fork, then add wet ingredients.)

For a sweeter bread, add 2 - 3 more TBS sugar.

For a delicious variation, add 1/2-1 can no-salt-added sweet corn (drained) or 1/2 -1 can cream corn to taste.

text:
I now live in New Zealand and only used 1/3 of the called-for sugar and it was still even sweet for the savoury palates of kiwis (and now, me).  It was perfect this way for my family, guests and I.  Best of all, no drying out!  Reheated in the oven/toaster (I know!) and it crunched on the outer, moist on the inner, didn't need butter!
I sprinkled cornmeal in the baking pan, and also topped the uncooked mixture with a bit of sugar and then salt to give it a sweet/savoury taste.  Perfect thank you!

text:
I almost melted all the butter in an 8" skillet in the oven. I poured the butter into a mixing bowl just before it finished melting (so I didn't burn it). I put the skillet straight back in the oven then added the other ingredients to the butter in the mixing bowl. I mixed the buttermilk and the baking soda in a measuring jug before pouring it into the mixing bowl. By the time the mixture was ready, the skillet was hot. The mixture is quite thick so needed leveling. It was perfectly cooked in 30 minutes.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the instructions and the only thing i did differently was substitute the sugar for equal sweetener. I was slightly disappointed because i made this cornbread to have with homemade chicken noodle soup which was delicious by the way. I should have had a back up like jiffy or store bought cornbread because i had nothing else to go with the soup not even crackers. I still enjoyed the soup by itself but it's not the same without cornbread. I would not recommend this recipe to anyone because in my opinion it is misleading. I do not want to make it again either unless it's used for cornbread dressing. It's dense texture and bland flavor or lack of flavor will make a perfect base for cornbread dressing. I give this recipe an extra star because it wasn't dry and it was surprisingly moist and had a picture perfect golden look  which was deceiving after i took the first bite i was like wtf!

None
text:
I used this recipe - without having tried it - to make nine pans of cornbread for my churchs chili cook-off. I cannot tell you what a HUGE hit it was. Everyone was asking who brought the cornbread, and I finally had to post the recipe. It is moist and sweet, without  the bitterness  you often get with a mix. It rises a lot while it bakes so I got 16  2X2 pieces out of each pan. I highly recommend this recipe! I used white flour and baked it for 30 minutes, but note the authors suggestion of using whole wheat flour and cooking for closer to 40 minutes if you want to reduce the sweetness.  Thank you, Bethany!

userID:
1610562
Display Name:
Mrs. W
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

7

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is absolutely the best cornbread on the planet! Made it for the 4th time yesterday. On the 1st try, & again yesterday, I put the baking soda in with the flour mixture instead of mixing it in with the buttermilk as per directions (my error). This didn't make a difference as far as taste goes When done correctly, it sort of reacts w/the buttermilk, & I think it may help with making the batter rise a bit.
I don't own an 8" square pan (or an iron skillet either). Made it in a 9" square non-stick pan, & that worked very well.
Sometimes there were add-ins before baking. My guys like jalapeno peppers sliced up, seeds & all. Used a good sized pepper, & don't ever forget the cheddar cheese......used 2/3 cup of the shredded stuff from the store. Chopped that up in the mini  chopper to make the shreds a bit shorter.
Fried bacon also goes in with the jalapenos as well. Usually make 4-6 thick slices, then crumble it in with the rest of the add ins.
Fear not.....this cornbread is great even w/o add-ins! A keeper in this family for sure!

Melanie Wiens Craddock

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2911436.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the only cornbread recipe you will ever need, it's that perfect!  I follow the recipe, but make a couple of small alterations in technique.  One, I mix the buttermilk and baking soda together in a measuring cup before I start doing anything else.  The time that it sits allows it to foam up, and it makes the cornbread so fluffy it comes all the way up to the top of the pan as it bakes!  Also, after I butter my pan, I put it in the preheating oven while I'm mixing up the batter.  I always like to pour cornbread batter into a hot pan, gives a nice crust.  Stop looking for a cornbread recipe, this is it!
Review:
Rating:
5

I would have taken a picture of this gorgeous golden bread, but it was gone before I had the chance! Made a double batch to serve with ribs. It was delish plain, with butter, or with honey butter. I subbed vinegar and milk for buttermilk, as I didnt want to run to the store. I also made sure to beat every ingredient in, as I dislike gritty, lumpy cornbread. It was super smooth... not too sweet... not too moist. Pretty dang perfect! Thank you Allrecipes!

My go-to cornbread recipe. I cut the butter to 1/4 cup and add 1/4 cup plain Greek yogurt. Reduce the sugar to 1/4 cup and fold in half a can of creamed corn (about 7 oz.) before pouring into the baking dish. It comes out super moist and flavorful.

Ive never made cornbread before. It seems to have its roots in the U.S., but not where I live. I had a feeling it be a perfect accompaniment to some stew I was making. Having said that, I found this recipe was quick, delicious, and easy. Instead of white sugar, I sweetened with 1/2 cup raw honey. Also, didnt want to buy a whole carton of buttermilk so I just watered down some Greek yoghurt. Even with these subs the bread was moist with a nice cakey texture. I will make this again.

text:
I dont usually have buttermilk around so I mix 1 cup milk and 1 1/2 tbs white vinegar to sour it.  Then I added 2 tbs thick sour cream (Gaylea Gold),  and 1 1/2 tbs honey.

Sometimes, if I want a bit denser less crumbly cornbread I add an extra egg.  

Even without my modifications, this is the best!

country:
None
text:
I made this and it came out wonderful.  Moist and just sweet enough.  For those that made it and got scrambled eggs - melt the butter and let it cool for 3 minutes, transfer to a large bowl and mix all ingredients in the bowl and then pour in pan to bake.  If you get scrambled eggs, the butter is too hot and if you mix it in the same pan you have additional heat from the pan.

I've made this several times now, and here's what I've adjusted.  I found that it really could use more leavening....a half of teaspoon of soda for whole pan of cornbread?  I also add 2 tsp. of baking powder.  I do like to use whole wheat pastry flour and I prefer the coarse ground cornmeal--it makes for a heartier cornbread.  Thanks for the recipe, Bethany!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-06-04T21:44:23.82
helpfulCount:

text:
This is my new go-to cornbread recipe I've made it probably 10 times one little thing I do different I Heat a cast iron skillet on the eye of my stove with just a touch of melted butter while I mix the cornbread when the pan is good and hot and the butter is starting to sizzle I pour the mix into the pan and leave it on the stove about 3 to 5 minutes until it starts to make bubbles like a pancake that gives it a very very crisp outer layer it is delicious

text:
Works for mini muffins! I used this for the small mini muffin trays and baked them for 10 - 11 minutes at 400 degrees. Made a double batch and split it because I wanted to add some jalapeos and corn to some of them. Worked out perfectly and both the plain and spicy were delicious! Followed the recipe exactly except on the spicy batch I added 1/4 cup diced canned jalapeos, 1/4 cup canned white corn and 1/2 cup shredded pepper jack cheese. I thought they were going to be too sweet after I tasted the batter but once they were baked, all the flavors melded nicely and for me it was just the right amount of sweetness.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A better way to make this recipe. I found the directions confusing, so went back to a more standard, easier way. 
1. Melt the butter in a  9 or 10 inch oven proof skillet (I use Circulon). 2. Combine the dry ingredients. 3. Beat the eggs into the buttermilk and combine with the dry ingredients. 4. Add melted butter to the batter and mix well. 5. Brush remaining butter around the skillet until all sides are coated and pour the batter into the skillet. 6. Bake for 30 minutes. 
Optional changes. We use gluten free all purpose flour and 1/2 cup sugar. So far nobody has been able to tell that it is gluten free. Everybody loves this cornbread.!

text:
Love the ingredients list. Can't stand the instructions. Each step is fraught with danger. 

I melt the butter and sugar together while preheating. 
Whisk the dry ingredients. 
Whisk the eggs and buttermilk.
Temper the eggs/buttermilk with the melted butter/eggs. 
Combine the custard and dry ingredients. 

Browning the butter is always delicious. I always replace half (or all) the flower with an 8-1 almond meal and coconut flower combination.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7789728.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I never  made cornbread before, or used buttermilk before, but this sounded so good I had to try it.I followed the recipe exactly.  I used a well seasoned #5 cast iron skillet (8 diameter, 2 deep) Preheated, with a 1/2 teaspoon of bacon fat for 10 min. at oven temp stated on this recipe. I made  the batter while the skillet preheated. Then I spread the bacon fat all around the inside edges and bottom with a paper towel and quickly added the batter to the hot skillet ..Got the sizzle! The cornbread rose to 1+6/8 along the edges and 1+7/8 in the center. Did not overflow, which was a concern, but it was the perfect skillet for the batter amount. I Let it cool for ten minutes and used a silicone spatula to lift out of the pan and put it on a dinner plate. It was still hot, but it had released from the bottom of the skillet, so it was a easy removal. One piece left..so it was a hit! Just used butter on the warm cornbread when we ate it. Yummy...will definitely make again now that we know how good it actually is!

This turned out fantastic.  I had never made cornbread before so I decided to be adventurous and bake it in my 10 inch cast iron skillet.  I placed the skillet in a 375 degree oven while I prepared the batter. I then added about a tablespoon of clarified butter to the skillet to melt before pouring in the batter and baking it for about 20 minutes.  The wedges just glided out of the skillet. I found the end result to be very tasty and my husband ended up eating half of it in one sitting.  My made no changes to the ingredients and will absolutely make it again. Thank you for sharing this great recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used this cornbread to top a pie made of beans, diced tomatoes, onions, ground beef, chipotle peppers and So Delicious non-dairy cheese. It was awesome. Due to dietary restrictions, I had to make modifications and will share them in case anyone else is dairy/gluten/soy-free and is wondering how it would turn out: swapped in Bob's Red Mill 1 for 1 gluten free flour for standard flour; used coconut milk with a splash of apple cider vinegar instead of buttermilk; used Smart Balace soy-free spread instead of butter; lastly used 1/2 cup sugar because I was concerned the coconut milk had some sweetness to it already. And it was still as fabulous as everyone said it was when following the original instructions! 

Thank you for sharing!

text:
I followed Grandmother's recipe exactly as written and incorporated all her personal changes. 
Oven was 375 degrees for exactly 30 minutes. I did as instructed and melted the butter in the pot, then removed pot from the stove and added sugar, beaten eggs, stirred a few times then added all the other ingredients. Poured in the greased 8x8 pan and baked for 30 minuted. This was so moist and by far the best corn bread recipe I have ever made. I did make my own buttermilk to save money, 1 cup of milk and tsp of white vinegar. Outstanding. DON'T CHANGE A THING WITH THIS RECIPE AND IF YOU DO WRITE YOUR OWN RECIPE AS THIS IS GRANDMOTHER'S

I made this yesterday for the first time ever -  and it came out perfect.   Since I was cooking it in an iron skillet - I needed more batter - so I changed the amounts by 1.5. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is wonderful recipe for some good homemade cornbread. Instead of melting butter in the pan, I just put butter in a cup and microwave it for a minute. I then pour the melted butter in an aluminum pan and added some sugar to it.  I did not put that much sugar in the mixture as  I don't care for sweet cornbread. Next, I  added the eggs, baking soda, buttermilk, cornmeal, unbleached flour, and salt into the aluminum pan and then stir  until blended together. This will reduce time of cleaning dishes afterwards. I baked the cornbread uncovered  for 25 minutes rather than 40 minutes to avoid cornbread being so tough and let it cool for at least 15 minutes. Once it's cool, I ate it with some collard/turnip greens and boy was it delicious!!
Review:

text:
This is an interesting recipe. Texture seems very spongy but my husband loved it. It is very sweet. Reduce sugar to your taste. I used an iron skillet hoping for a crispy bottom but it wasn't crispy. The top, however; was crisp & brown. One suggestion that might make the texture less spongy is to pour them thinner. I also noticed that as they sat on the counter, the spongy texture was not so spongy.

text:
I've been using the recipe from the cornmeal  box to make cornbread for the past 20 years, with disappointing results every time. The end product was usually dry and lacking in flavor. I would always have to ask the next day, "Who wants to finish off this cornbread?" Eventually, the last piece or two would end up in the trash (and I am not one who takes the wasting of food lightly! I would gladly have eaten those last pieces of substandard cornbread myself if I wasn't on a low-carb diet! I cook things like this for my carb hungry family!) I figured it was time for a change. My family loves my homemade chili, which I like to serve with cornbread, so I thought I should find a cornbread recipe that would do it justice. Hallelujah! This is it! Now I know what was missing from my cornbread all this time! Buttermilk and butter! Those made all the difference between "meh" cornbread and "is there any left?" cornbread! From now on, this is my go-to cornbread recipe. My family, my chili, my trash can, and my thrifty-minded conscience thank you!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Great recipe! I'd definitely make this again though as someone else suggested, I cut the sugar to 1/2 a cup. I don't like my cornbread overly sweet though it is delicious served with a smidge of butter and honey. 

I took it out of the oven after 30 minutes and it was perfectly browned and very moist but baked through. I made it for Thanksgiving and have a feeling there won't be leftovers.  This recipe was very easy to make, I didn't even need to get my mixer out; a spoon worked just fine. Also, to save washing pots/pans I microwaved the butter  for 2 minutes in a small dish, to melt it. 

Everything mixed up fine in one bowl and then I poured into a greased glass baking dish. Easy clean up. I greased with butter for flavour (as opposed to some other oil). Happy baking!

text:
I'm normally not a cornbread fan because it's too dry for me. However, I needed to bring corn bread to a BBQ potluck, so tried this recipe. It was so easy to make and outstanding! I got rave reviews from everyone!. If you like Southern cornbread you won't like this because its not dry and savory; it's more like  a cake (moist and buttery).  However, I totally loved it (and so did my husband) and didn't even need to put honey and butter on! It is a little too sweet for me, so next time I'll cut back on the sugar. I also substituted some real Class B maple syrup to add a slightly more complex taste profile, and added some shredded jalapeno jack cheese.
Review:
Rating:
1

2017-07-15T03:08:40.537

I think I would lower temp to 350 for a 9x13.  I only had 2/3 cup white sugar so I used 2/3 cup brown too.  (I doubled recipe so needed 1 1/3 cup sugar.

text:
This recipe is a keeper.  I like my cornbread on the sweeter side, so this was perfect.  I didn't change the ingredients at all, but I did bake it in a cast iron pan because I like the crust crispy.  This was definitely NOT cakey or dense.  The texture was perfect in my book.

Changes I made....12" cast iron pan smoking hot on high heat.  Quickly buttered it up.  Poured the mixture into the pan.  Let it cook for maybe a minute.  Put it in the oven at 450 for 18 minutes.  Was perfect.

text:
This was pretty darn good.  I would make it again.  I had some coconut oil that I wanted to use up, so 1/2 butter and 1/2 coconut oil.  Didn't have all purpose flour, so I used bread  flour. Used instant buttermilk. Mis-read recipe and used 1.5 tsp of baking powder.  Mixed all dry ingredients together. Mixed egg and water (from instant buttermilk) together then added in melter butter/oil.   Mixed wet into dry. And it still came out really tasty.  Has a little bit of a coconut taste, which seems to work well.

text:
I followed the directions except I put all wet ingredients into a separate mixing bowl and combined all dry ingredients into another bowl.  Threw them all together into another bowl and mixed.  Then I heated a cast iron, 10 inch skillet with a 1/4 cup of vegetable oil on a stove on medium heat,  and poured all ingredients in a it simmered for a minute.  Then baked for 5 minutes less then the called recipe.  If you like crunchy on the outside and moist on the inside, this works.

userID:
16775550
Display Name:
Karen
isPro:
False

1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent! I am a born & raised Tennessean. I don't usually eat sweet cornbread. This recipe isn't too sweet & can be modified to be less sweet by reducing the amount of sugar. I always, always? use cast iron for cornbread & did so here. Bakes about 20-25 minutes & turns out beautifully. For those who fuss about true southern cornbread, many use those bags of cornmeal mix (entirely different from boxes of jiffy mix!) Let me assure you guys who use that product that you are indeed using sugar in your cornbread because it's already in those big 5# bags! I think the secret to the success of this recipe is the melted butter & buttermilk. Many in our area do not use eggs in cornbread because of the more cakelike result. I include eggs in my cornbread always because I think it improves texture & also increases the nutritional value of the bread. I recommend the first time you make this recipe, make exactly as written whether you make it in a separate saucepan where you melt the butter or in a bowl. Makes great muffins which are easier to freeze for individual servings portions or for church potluck dinner dinners! Thanks for a great recipe!

Excellent!  Very easy to make--I prepped all the ingredients first and had them "at the ready" to put into the 3 qt skillet.  I wasn't absolutely certain whether I should beat the eggs before adding or beat them in with the warm butter and sugar, so I opted to lightly beat before adding.  The end result was moist, tasty and with a good cornbread sweetness.  Will make again!

text:
Some people are obviously suffering under the impression that only 'Southerners' eat cornbread. A) Not everyone likes corn meal flavored styrofoam. B) There are a lot of 'Southerners' that like a little or a lot of sweetener in their cornbread. C) Cornbread existed long before Europeans got to the New World. Deal with it.

This cornbread was delicious. I liked it even better when I subbed out the white sugar for honey.

text:
Made it in my small rice cooker and worked perfectly! Twenty minutes on one side and less than ten on the other. Little editions for half the suggested serving: half a cup minus one tablespoon of soy milk, one tablespoon apple cider, and two tablespoons of yogurt in stead of the buttermilk, and two and a half tablespoons of honey instead of the sugar. The dough was pretty thick this time so maybe I should add more of my "buttermilk". The cornmeal was a little bit dry but the sweetness and the sourness was perfect!

text:
great recipe - as mentioned i used a cast iron skillet that pre-heated in the oven - my 12 inch (outside diameter) - was just a little bit too large since it resulted in only a 1.25 inch height - perhaps a little more baking soda would have providing a better rise. One tip is to get the final batter in the oven quickly since it gets very dry-like just after mixing so make sure the skillet is ready for it before mixing. With all that, the taste was outstanding - and make sure to use Yellow corn meal, not white

Display Name:
Michelle B

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/1747.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this to go with the Roasted Tomato Soup recipe, also from this site. It is so delicious, I had to make sure I froze the leftovers right away or I'd make myself sick eating the whole pan. I almost gave it 4 stars due to a few issues, but then realized I love it regardless, so it still earns 5 stars. 

Issues: 
1.  It seemed strange to prep it in the skillet but then put it in a different, square pan to bake (I used a stone baker). Why not just keep it in the skillet? Next time I will.

2. Very sweet. It's good, but I don't associate cornbread with this amount of sweetness. I didn't put any butter or honey or anything on it. It didn't need it. I'm on the fence about what I think about this... love  the cornbread but would kind of like to at my own sweetness upon serving/eating.

3. The cornmeal ended up grittier in the end result than usual. I think next time I'll let it soak a few minutes in the buttermilk mixture before adding it to the pan.

Otherwise, great! I don't feel I can make it for guests yet until I deal  with the grittiness issue. While cornbread probably should be a little gritty, this was uncomfortably so.

text:
I cut all ingredients in half. Used soured milk instead of buttermilk. I then cooked in a loaf pan for 30 minutes. The bread came out nice but had little rising, ending up being about 1" high when done. The bread was good & I would make again.

text:
I have made this as written many times.  Our family likes cornbread the traditional way and sweet.  This recipe is the sweet variety.  The cornmeal keeps it from getting to cake like and gives it some texture.  It was very moist and not at all crumbly.  If you hate sweet cornbread, then this is not for you.  If you like sweet cornbread or are open to trying it, then this will likely be a keeper recipe for you.  Maybe next time I will try some additions like corn kernels or jalapeos.  We have always had it plain and served with fresh butter and honey. Time to tweak things a bit.

text:
First time I threw it out as it was too sweet, dry and flavourless.  Second time ignored the sugar and added a can of niblet corn  - tasted better and not dry. I mixed it in a bowl and not a skillet and I also buttered the 8x8 pan and put it in the oven for a couple of minutes to warm up.

text:
Hands down the best cornbread I ever ate. But since I am gluten free I had to change the recipe. Instead of flour I used coconut flour. I also added 1 tsp of baking powder. I was afraid it would not work because it was like mashed potatoes instead of a pourable batter. I squeezed the batter into my corn bread pan (cast iron) and lowered the temp by 25 degrees. It took 5 minutes more to cook to a golden brown (I'm at high altitude). The came out beautiful- moist, sweet, and no need for butter. This is my favorite corn bread now.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great cornbread recipe!  Slightly sweet.  I let my glass pan preheat in oven before pouring in batter.  When ready to pour in batter I first rubbed butter along all sides of pan and when it started to pool up in bottom of pan I poured in the batter.  Had an excellent crust because of this.  I also added one finely chopped onion, half a fine chopped bell pepper, and 1/4 cup chopped jarred jalapeo.  Then sprinkled cheddar cheese on top.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/150803.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe! I was craving cornbread so bad, last time I had some was 8 years ago when I used to live in the US, but my hubby always discouraged me from making it because he didn't like it and didn't care for it. I made this recipe today and boy, I loved it! light and moist, perfect texture and consistency.  The only change I made was lowering the amount of sugar. My kids didn't like mixing this bread with salty foods ( they put it down as soon as they took a bite of the beans I served and reached for the salty bread instead), but they devoured it later as a dessert. This could be a successful option for breakfast, with warm milk and syrup, but as a bread for dinner, I would have to tweak the recipe and make it salty instead. I will definitely make this again as written, but it will definitely be for a sweet breakfast.

text:
I love the way this recipe turned out. It was moist and not overly sweet.  I have no concerns whether it is a traditional Southern Cornbread recipe as it is delicious; family and friends love it.  I grew up with a thinner unsweetened cornbread with no added flour or leavening agent.  My father crumbled his piece up and added it to his glass of milk and ate the soggy cornbread with a spoon; also a Southern tradition. It's not a matter of right or wrong, southern or northern... its a matter of people free to make a choice as what pleases their pallet no matter where they live.  Thank you for sharing this recipe.

country:
None
text:
I've made this a bunch of times and I always did the same way until tonight. BAKE IN A CAST IRON SKILLET YOU WON'T REGRET IT!! So always was afraid to just throw it all in there and into the oven. Laziness got the better of me tonight and so glad  it did cuz the crust was just so perfect! I make the recipe as written and always transferred it into a glass baking dish. Never again! That is the only thing wrong with this whole recipe. Oh, the other thing I do is make my own "buttermilk" because it's never something I keep on hand: 1 tablespoon of white vinegar in a glass measuring cup and add enough milk to make 1 cup. My cast iron skillet  is a 12" I think. I was afraid it was too big. It isn't - but only took just shy of 30 minutes to bake to a beautiful golden brown. Don't worry about greasing it: between the butter in the recipe and a well-seasoned pan there was no problem getting the corn bread out - even after completely cooled.

text:
Love this recipe.  I make the batter exactly as described.  I do, however change up the pan that it's baked in.  Instead of a round pan or a loaf pan, I make it in two mini-muffin trays. (Usually makes 24). This way there's more crunchy surface area. I bake the trays for 30 minutes.  And to add extra crispness I usually broil on high for one minute (always watching to prevent burning). This recipe is a favourite of mine - and even my foodie friends are impressed.

text:
Needed to make a good homemade cornbread for my Thanksgiving cornbread dressing and I had plenty of fresh ground cornmeal. Saw the reviews for this one and gave it a try. The recipe is excellent as written, but I had to make a few modifications since this was for a dressing. I increased the salt to a full teaspoon because I used unsalted butter, decreased the sugar to 1/2 cup, and I only needed to bake mine for about 25 minutes. It was so good! Will definitely make this again.

text:
I made it with grits instead of corn meal and it still came out great.   Also "made" buttermilk using evaporated 2% milk and apple cider vinegar.  Not overly sweet with cake-lIke texture.   Heated my greased pan while preheating oven before adding batter.  Perfect with our Chili.  Probably great base for corn bread stuffing.  Excellent recipe.   30 minutes exactly for perfection.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is by far my family's favorite cornbread recipe.   Followed the recipe to the letter the first time.  Wanted to cut back on sugar and butter a bit and found we like it much better.  I used 5 TBSP butter and melted in sm/med cast iron pan. Reduced sugar to 1/2 cup and also added 2 tsp of baking powder. Poured batter back in the cast iron pan.   My convection oven bakes much faster, so I check for doneness about 28 minutes.  Wonderful recipe.  I think the buttermilk is the key ingredient.

country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe countless time. Quite often I also add 2 cups of blueberries (fresh or frozen) to a double recipe. Sprinkle 1 Tbl flour over blueberries , put half the batter in the pan, the layer of blueberries and top with the other half of batter. Using this method the berries do not sink to the bottom. A great, great recipe and the only one I go to!

None
text:
Just pulled mine out of the oven and I really like how light and lightly sweet it is. It is exactly what I had hoped for. I made it to ultimately try out a wild mushroom stuffing recipe, but will have some in the am for breakfast. My substitutions were minor compared to other reviews: I didn't have baking soda - I misread the recipe and bought baking powder, so substituted 1/2 tea. baking soda for 1&1/2 tea baking powder, and omitted the salt. I also didn't have fresh buttermilk, but since I don't drink it, I saved my last container by pouring it in plastic containers and freezing. I only had a half pint, so defrosted that and used it. No water, no milk, no lemon...

text:
After being dissatisfied with cornbread mixes and other cornbread  recipes, this is a winner!!  It turned out well in the end.  

I baked it in the correct size  of pan, but it was sitting on a pizza stone.  (I think that messed things up.)   I took it out after checking the center with a toothpick.  It cooled for 5 minutes.  I flipped it over and a mound of  raw batter was stuck to the center of the pan and the bottom was not done.  I took out the pizza stone, turned the oven back on,  flipped the cornbread back in the pan, and baked it for 10 more minutes.  When I flipped it over, the bottom center had fused back in and the cornbread had a perfect consistency.  It also tasted great.

Display Name:
fillifelle
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cake surprised me, the texture was perfect, crumbly and moist. I wanted to follow the recipe exactly but autopilot kicked in and I accidentally mixed the sugar in with the dry ingredients as I usually do, instead of into the butter.  I don't think it affected the end result at all. This is a very forgiving recipe. I baked it in a SKILLET after reading the reviews, and let me tell you, if you've never baked anything in a cast iron skillet before you gotta try it. I was so impressed, the rise was even, cook time was faster, didn't stick at all on the sides and bottom (gotta preheat it tho), such a beautiful golden browning on the sides and bottom. I am considering baking all my future cakes in cast iron now! Of course, it could also be due to the recipe that the cake turned out so well. 
I used medium grind cornmeal (Bob's Red Mill) and this may have contributed to the crumbliness. My Guess is a fine grind cornmeal will yield a denser, more pound cake like texture.
I also didn't have all purpose flour on hand and substituted half cup organic whole wheat flour and half cup cake flour.
I melted my butter in the microwave in the bowl I used to mix all the wet ingredients in. Less washing up.
And by the way 375F translates to 190C, not 175 as stated on the website.

5

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is great!  I make it all the time; it is my go-to cornbread!  I did, however, make one change...by accident at first, but then thought it turned out so great that I permanently amended it.  I used two sticks of butter instead of one.  When I first made the recipe, I misread it as one cup of butter instead of a half cup.  I thought it was buttery, moist and delicious!  On a later date, I made the recipe correctly, and I felt I was missing the moist consistency of the first.  When I make it the original way, it needs a bit of butter when slicing and serving; when I make it with the extra stick of butter, it needs no extra when serving.  I think it just comes down to personal preference and whether you prefer it more crumbly (and probably more true to its origin....hence the one stick of butter in the original recipe) or more moist and cake-like.  Either way, this is a keeper!

This is my go-to cornbread recipe.  I've easily made it a dozen times over the years & it's always a winner.  I catered a rehearsal  dinner, Southern BBQ theme & made this. I have done it in pre-heated cast iron & it does give a great crust to the bread!  But normally I just do it in the square pan.  That's it for tweaks.  Perfect as is.

text:
I really enjoyed this recipe. I made slight changes, one being that I cut the sugar by 1/3 as not everyone in my family likes sweet cornbread and also I made it in a cast iron skillet. It came out more cake like and not so dense but it was moist, with just a slight touch of sweetness. I will definitely use this as my go to recipe as I can adjust the sweetness or omit it if I want. For those of you who do not use buttermilk often, consider buttermilk powder it lasts a long time in the refrigerator.

I was very glad and surprised that it was not sweeter. Where I live in the south, cornbread is not sweet.
As another review suggested, I made muffins. I like to do this, put each in a ziplock snack bag, then put them in a larger bag and freeze. I then can take out the amount I need and warm them slightly in the microwave.
The reason that i didn't rate it higher is that mine turned out kind of dry.
I make another recipe this way and they are not dry. Maybe a little more buttermilk was needed!

text:
I happen to like sweet cornbread and this one was great! I did however tweak it  to my situation: I rarely use buttermilk - don't judge me - so I used sour milk (half a squeezed lemon per cup of milk).  Also, hot butter in a pan with beaten eggs means scrambled to me, so I used a glass bowl to melt the butter then did the rest exactly according to the recipe. I began checking for done-ness at about 20 minutes and it only cooked it for about 23 minutes. Thank you Bethany it was perfect!

userID:
7332830
Display Name:
peng1pete
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
23
favoritesCount:
162
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe, with changes. I always cut the sugar at least in half (and sometimes use honey or brown sugar),  often use half white and half whole wheat flour, and soak the cornmeal in the buttermilk for about twenty minutes if I'm using a coarser cornmeal. I throw the butter in the pan and put it in the oven to melt to start (saves greasing the pan). Instead of buttermilk, I replace a tablespoon of milk with a tablespoon of white vinegar, stir well, and let sit for ten minutes.

I've also scaled it up to 14 servings (from its current nine), poured it in a jelly roll pan, and baked it for 22 minutes to make bite size servings for a chili cook off, and it worked great.

text:
I cut the sugar to 1/2 cup and substituted 1/2 cup whole wheat flour for half of the white flour. I also baked the batter in my trusty 10 inch cast iron skillet and was careful not to overbake. It was moist and delicious--not dry and bland like many other cornbread recipes I've made. When I make it again, I may cut the sugar down to 1/3 cup, because 1/2 cup was plenty sweet for me. Best cornbread recipe I've made, and thanks to everyone's suggestions!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As a Southerner mama taught me it's bad manners to criticize a recipe GIVEN to you even if it's not for you. She also said that it's an insult to tell the giver of the recipe how you changed it to make it better. Unless asked to, keep it to yourself & be gracious. If you don't like it say thank you & be on your way.  If you LOVE it tell the chef why and thank him or her.  I have never heard Southerners protest that something was TOO sweet unless they were describing grandma herself.  As in "Grandma is being way too sweet, what's up with that?"

Nice that allrecipes is asking us to rate it and how we might change it. It's probably more than Grandma would do.

I loved everything about it. Thank you!

text:
Awesome cornbread!!!!! This is my permanent chili companion. I also love the easy clean up as you can mix all the ingredients in one pot before transferring it to a baking dish. I use salted butter so I don't add any additional salt. Check it after 20-minutes to avoid overbaking/dryness!!! Then check at 5-min increments until a toothpick in the center comes out clean. You won't find a better or tastier cornbread recipe.

text:
This recipe makes a delicious cornbread - moist and a little sweet.  I just made a couple of small changes.  I doubled the recipe and used 1 c sugar and 1/3 c honey; I also used the powdered buttermilk mixed with water as others suggested.  I microwaved the butter in a large bowl and then added the ingredients to that bowl.  I baked it in a 13x9" pan for about 30 minutes.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe (and I've tried many), though I never quite make it the same twice. Recently, I substituted half the all purpose flour with corn flour and it was so much more flavorful. Next time I will try just corn flour instead of all purpose. I also prefer to make them as muffins (without paper cups) because then you get more of the lovely crunchy exterior and they reheat lovely individually in the oven. I line the muffin pan with Crisco and cook at 350 (convection) for 20 minutes. One recipe makes one dozen full size muffins, sometimes I stretch it to 18 muffins to make them a little smaller.
I've also tried adding a can or corn, but I find that all the moisture gets sucked out of the corn into the batter and you're left with small chewy bits rather than nice plump corn.

text:
I confess to a bit of a sweet tooth so I like my cornbread sweeter than not. A cast iron skillet in the oven while it heats up makes for a wonderfully crispy edge. The batter should sizzle a little when you pour it in the skillet.  Turn the skillet over when it has cooled a bit after cooking and the bread just falls out. Thirty minutes was the perfect cooking time! Really delicious with no tweaks.

text:
I'm a New Englander, so I guess I'm genetically predisposed to like my cornbread a little sweet. That said, I cut the sugar a little by keeping it at 2/3 cup while increasing all other ingredients by a half. I increased the recipe because I decided to bake it in my 10" cast iron skillet. I pre melted 2 TBSP of butter in the skillet and made sure to cover the sides. I'm glad I kept a close eye on it because it was done baking at about the 25 minute mark. This is THE BEST cornbread I ever made. Next time I might decrease the sugar even slightly more. It's by no means too sweet, but whenever I can cut sugar without compromising taste, I'll do it.

text:
This was a great recipe - sweet but not too sweet and very moist.  I think the order of ingredients was a little strange.  I like the idea of combining the melted butter and sugar together, which cools down the melted butter.  But otherwise, I combined all the dry ingredients in a bowl, then added all the wet ingredients (after butter cooled a little) and stirred.  VERY easy and really delicious!

text:
I made this for my family for New Year's day, and everyone loved it. I multiplied the recipe by 1-1/2 and got 16 servings. I baked mine in a HOT, oiled 10" cast iron skillet for 22 minutes. Do NOT overbake! Keep an eye on it for the last couple of minutes.

3/4 cup butter
1 cup sugar
3 eggs
1-1/2 cups buttermilk
3/4 teaspoon baking soda
1-1/2 cups cornmeal
1-1/2 cups all-purpose flour
3/4 teaspoon salt

Easy and delicious! I made this exactly as written, didn't add a thing. It is a sweet cornbread but not too sweet. It pairs well with soups, stews or a country dinner. text:
I really like this recipe! I followed it to a T and it came out great. I did however cut back on the sugar, only adding about 3/4 of what the recipe calls for. I love the texture and moisture. It doesn't leave your mouth dry like many others. Some like that but I prefer a soft texture. However, one time I made these they came out too soft, almost mushy. I did add a bit more buttermilk just to finish off the bottle, but I wouldn't think it was enough to completely change the texture. But maybe, because every other time I've made it without any additions, it came out great!

None
text:
This is my fiancee's favourite version of cornbread. Whenever she gets a craving, this is what I make. As to baking tips, I saw the author post about the cooking time. The easiest way to judge is to watch the top. It shouldn't get overly dark. If it does, it will be dry and a little burnt. You want it to just start to darken, and for a toothpick stuck in the middle to come out clean.

text:
Very good!  I used my new silicone bakeware making this cornbread today, including the 8" pan.  I didn't use cooking spray and the bread came out of the pan perfectly.  I would say mine turned out a teeny bit dry, so I'll need to continue experimenting with the silicone bakeware, and adjust the baking time a bit (took it out at 30 mins).  I would recommend to other bakers to have all ingredients measured and ready to use as the mixing goes very quickly once the butter is melted.

text:
Did everything in the recipe except for the buttermilk which I didn't have. I made my own by mixing 1/2 cup evaporated milk, 1/2 cup water and 1 tbsp vinegar; let stand for 5 minutes. Mixed everything in one pot where the butter was melted and poured in a square pan. It turned out perfect after 30 minutes. I didn't even test for doneness, I just grabbed it out of the oven and served on the table. It was good! The kids liked it a lot.

text:
Best cornbread recipe I've ever made. I make this on Thanksgiving and Christmas every year and my fiance's family loves it. I always mix the batter in a cast iron skillet and then put the whole skillet in the oven, instead of using a separate baking dish. I learned to bake breads in cast iron from my Irish grandfather - that's how we made Irish soda bread - and I love the extra flavor the cast iron imbues into the bread.

text:
Oh my... my boyfriend (a foodie) said it was best cornbread ever.  I used Schoch's (Salinas, CA) non-homogenized, non-pasteurized yogurt instead of buttermilk, and red floriani flint corn polenta from Coke Farm (San Juan Bautista, CA) instead of regular cornmeal.    I also halved the sugar because we don't like ours real sweet.  Plus, I placed the batter into a hot buttered iron skillet to bake instead of square pan.  (Be sure to butter sides of pan too!)  Brown and crispy bottom; textured but not crumbly body.  Can't wait to make again!

userID:
4819405
Display Name:
Suzy-Q
isPro:

1

35
favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm on a fixed income and cannot afford to risk wasting ingredients. So I changed the assembly technique somewhat and reduced the sugar to 1/2 a cup, because I don't like real sweet cornbread. Here's what I did: melted the butter in a cast iron skillet, then added the sugar as directed. In a mixing bowl, I whisked together the eggs, added the buttermilk, baking soda and salt and whisked those together. Then I folded in the cornmeal and flour.  To that I then poured the butter / sugar mixture and folded that into the batter.  Poured all of that back into the skillet and baked in the 375 degree preheated oven for 30 minutes;  perfect. I just knew that I'd get scrambled eggs if I had tried to whisk those eggs into the hot butter sugar mixture, even though that mixture was 'off' the heat. In spite of those minor changes, I gave this five stars for the end result, 'cause I don't think my changes made that much difference. Best cornbread I've EVER had and I'm 60+ y/o.

5

I made these for a chili cook-off/potluck so cooked them in a mini muffin tin for ease of serving. I put the timer on for 20 min then got busy with something else and missed the timer.  So the overcooked. BUT they were still fairly moist and light and delicious. In fact I had to surrender my last one to a 3yo who was sad because all the "cupcakes" were gone. I have a new cornbread recipe.

Okay, I've made this a couple more times, keeping an eye on the time. They are amazing!

text:
This is the second time I am making this cornbread, the first , I followed the recipe exactly.It was delicious and really simple to make. I made a few tweaks but only because of personal preference. I used whole wheat  flour instead of all purpose; only 1/2 cup sugar and 1 egg, added 2 tbls more buttermilk. (Did not have buttermilk so used the suggestion of another reviewer and added lemon juice to milk). Finally, I added 1/2 teaspoon cayenne pepper, just for a little zing.
I really like corn bread and think I finally found my go to recipe. I would certainly make again.

text:
Instead of the 2/3 cup of sugar I subtracted about 2 tablespoons. I used the plain milk with lemon juice trick to sub for buttermilk (never a problem before).  I used a mini muffin tin and had enough batter left for a small ramkin.  I baked at 360 (reduced heat slightly since they were mini muffins) for about 25 mins. The bottoms were over done, while the rest was ok.  After cooling, the muffins were rock hard!!!  They also had no taste!  I think I will stick to this sites "Best Corn Muffins Ever" recipe.

text:
Just made this tonight, and wow... moist, delicious, and it baked up exactly as described by Bethany.  I did 2 things different:  I cut the sugar in half, mostly becuase I'm not a fan of really sweet things ( which is just a matter of taste)  and greased the pan with bacon grease and floured it well.  That was a tip from another reviewer... thank you for that tip!  Other than that, I followed the recipe exactly, made sure the oven was preheated, and checked it at 30 min.  I ended up leaving it in about 4 min more to brown the top a bit more, and it came out perfect.   Great combination of ingredients, and good clear instructions!

Confession time - I changed exactly half of the ingredients in the recipe. When I got out my cornmeal, I found that the bugs had been chomping on it. I ended up using quick grits. I then discovered I was out of buttermilk and white sugar. Sub cider vinegar + milk and honey. I then decided the chef's suggestion to sub whole wheat was a good one. Usually, I don't like to rate a recipe unless I've made it the way it was intended to be. However, I want myself to know that I liked this recipe the next time I make it! It was great! I'm sure it would be great the way it was written. I would probably cut the sugar down just a smidge, but still, fantastic.

Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2014-12-06T12:53:46.007
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
3252806
Display Name:
Curryholic
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
51
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/232355.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love savory more than sweet, so I use the recipe part to a T, except only 1/4 cup of sugar.  Then change up the process a bit. That's why I didn't give it a full 5. For southern style goodness, you want to use the whole stick of butter in the batter, and another 3 Tbsp in your 9" cast iron skillet. Keeps it super moist and, well, buttery! Heat up that extra bit of butter in the pan in the oven while you preheat it and mix the batter in a separate bowl, then carefully pour it into the hot, buttery skillet and bake as directed. The butter will ooze up the sides and over the top of the batter, making a beautiful crust. (If you get interrupted while mixing, though, pull out the pan so you don't scorch your butter.) Also key is the buttermilk...I don't keep that on hand, so I mix a half cup of plain full-fat ("traditional") Greek yogurt with enough whole milk (or even ranch dressing!) to make a cup, then stir in a Tbsp of lemon juice. Then, when you mix in the baking soda, it reacts and foams up really nicely, keeping the bread nice and fluffy.  t's also great with some corn or chilis or grated cheese or all of the above...just stir it into the batter before you pour it into the pan. It's dangerous to have this around the house because I find excuses to have just one more piece (warm and toasty with milk or cream soaked in for breakfast? Yes, please!) so before I know it' it's gone and I have to make more!

text:
Thank you! I've been searching for a corn bread recipe without boxes or white flour in the recipe - and this was close enough!  I substituted organic corn flour for the standard white flour, and only used half the sugar (corn is naturally sweet) - it turned out wonderful - very dense, but not dry, and much more "corn-y". My sweet tooth son adds a dollop of honey to his - otherwise a pat of butter and this is corn bread heaven.

text:
Good recipe, tasty cornbread. I used milk and vinegar for the buttermilk. I will do buttermilk next time because I think it will be even better. I used a casserole dish but cast iron is what I usually bake this kind of bread in. Turned out great.
2nd try: I melted the butter in my cast iron  in 375 degree oven and mixed slightly to dry ingredients, added buttermilk and the eggs so they wouldn't cook. The key is to not over mix. I spooned back into cast iron and set timer to 20 minted to continually check. I believe I have a 12" skillet. Best recipe I have found.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
For those true southerners who don't put sugar in their cornbread this isn't a southern cornbread.  For those of us in the rest of the country this is the best cornbread you'll ever eat!  I changed the directions but follow the ingredient list and amounts...I soak the cornmeal in the buttermilk first, then add the butter that I melted in the microwave and the eggs. Next I mix the rest of the dry ingredients in a large bowl and then combine with the wet ingredients. I take a tablespoon of butter and put it in my iron skillet and stick it the oven to melt and heat up the pan. I pour the batter into the iron skillet and bake for about 30 minutes until the cornbread is done.  It's fabulous!

text:
This is my go-to cornbread recipe.  I get compliments on it all the time. My one ingredient change is to drop the sugar to 1/2 c.  Mix all ingredients in a mixing bowl.  While measuring and mixing the cornbread ingredients, bring 1-2 tbs oil in a cast iron skillet to temperature in the oven. When the skillet is hot, pour in the batter and bake till golden on top.

I've tried this recipe exactly as it calls. Its absolutely delicious, and a bit sweet. I tried it a second time modified it for lower fat/sugar:
1/2 cup sugar instead of 3/4 cup sugar.
1/4 cup butter, 1/4 cup apple sauce instead of 1/2 cup butter.
It turned out great this way! Held it's consistency too. A definite winner.

text:
This recipe was so easy to prepare and it turned out great.  I did not have any buttermilk on hand so I substituted one cup of 2% milk and added one Tablespoon of vinegar. I let that stand while I measured the other ingredients.  Many reviewers have mentioned that sugar should not be added to "real" cornbread.  I thought this had a nice sweetness. I did not add honey or butter when I ate it.  I did not think this was overly sweet. I'm happy that I tried the recipe. And I thank Bethany for sharing her grandmother's recipe.

text:
This is my go-to recipe for cornbread! On cold winter days, I turn to this cornbread recipe along with the Creamy White Chicken Chili on this site. When I begin to preheat my oven, I put the butter in the baking pan and allow the butter to melt. Once it has melted, I follow the instructions as written. It really helps to only use the baking pan as the only dish. Also, I never have buttermilk on hand. So I put 1 tbls of lemon juice in my 1 cup measurer and add milk up to the 1 cup line. This works as a fabulous substitute. Thanks for adding!!

My family absolutely loved this recipe as it was moist and delicious! I didn't make any changes to the ingredients posted. userID:
10784485
Display Name:
dvargas76
isPro:

6

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1024810.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have to agree with a prior post, no true Southerner puts sugar in the cornbread.  I always use a tablespoon of left over bacon grease I collect in a canister specifically made for grease that strains it.  Heat it until it's starting to steam or it sizzles when you flick a drop of water in it.  Pour the grease over the cornmeal mix, stir, then put back into the pan while it's still hot, this makes the nice browned crust, then put it into the oven on 400F preferably.  I always use buttermilk as well.  If I want to make the cornbread sweet, I don't use sugar, I use honey.  There are also a bunch of different variations I do with the flavors that can be added.  This recipe above is a Northernized version.

text:
I made this last night for my family since it was the first snow of the year, and everyone loved it.  I have never made my own cornbread, just bought Jiffy.  This recipe was easy to follow and had amazing taste.  I followed the directions and cooked my cornbread in a preheated oven for 30 minutes and that was perfect.  I put my batter in a cast iron skillet to cook and it made it moist and fluffy.  Perfect recipe and will definitely use this again especially since it is so easy to make.  Like I said I have never cooked cornbread before and I did it the first time.  Thanks for a great recipe!!

text:
This was almost like dessert.  If you don't have buttermilk - use 1 c milk (less 2 Tbs) and add 2 Tbs lemon juice - let sit for a minute.  I also added 2/3 c drained canned corn.  Could use less sugar next time as it was great but just a tad too sweet.  Would be great with a layer of salsa as well.

country:
None
text:
I just made this for the first time and no sooner had I removed it from the pan to the cooling rack, both of my children (ages 1 & 2) went off like car alarms. They gobbled up the warm sample pieces, meaning, this recipe gets their approval. I followed the recipe almost exactly, only melting my butter in the microwave instead of a pan and used Karen's suggestion of mixing 2 Tbsp lemon juice with milk since I didn't have buttermilk. I'm not sure why everyone says this is too sweet, because for me, it tasted fine, though if you're looking for a more prominent corn flavor that the box mixes have, this isn't the recipe you're looking for.

country:

text:
OH, MY GOSH! This is WONDERFUL! I can not believe how good it was/is.
I followed the recipe exactly but added fresh corn and chopped pickled jalepeno in the batter.
I melted butter in a big stainless mixing bowl. I put a little bit of water in a frying pan and put that bowl in the pan. And then I did all the ingredients mixing in that bowl after melting the butter just like the owner of this recipe suggested. 
I was concerned about the amount of sugar, too especially after reading some reviews but I decided to follow one reviewer's advice saying that she doesn't like too sweet stuff but this one is definitely not too sweet. I have to agree with her. I can't stand too sweet stuff either. Well, I don't even use syrup when eating pancakes cause I think they are good enough without syrup. This one, I thought was perfect when it comes to sweetness. Don't get me wrong. It was sweet but it was delicious sweet NOT disgustingly sweet or too sweet.
Mine took a long time actually. It could be our stove or maybe the fact that I added fresh corn and jalepeno, or maybe the pan I used. I didn't have 9X9 pan so I used a bread pan. So it took good 40 minutes at 375 for me. I was worried that it might have dried out but it was PERFECT!
My hubby loved it, too. It went so well with tortilla soup I made from this site. I am definitely making it again. Yum, yum, yum..
