text:
I enjoy reading members varieties of the recipes!  How boring it would be to read reviews if they were all the same and all did the exact same thing.  Duh!  SO for my review, I have made this cornbread all my life and I am a grandma that learned it from my grandma.  Buttermilk is always the key in making cornbread.  Flour is another key because it makes it easier to consume without choking.  I make this with white cornmeal, not yellow.  I always use either a lodge cast iron skillet or a lodge cast iron biscuit pan.  I reduce the sugar and I reduce the flour.  In fact, I don't even measure.  I mix everything in a bowl.  I always heat the cast iron pans with oil first before pouring in the batter.  It's fun to play around with this recipe.  You can of course, make changes to suit your preferences and even make additions as in adding corn, etc.

None
text:
Best Cornbread recipe ever! I have used this recipe multiple times, and it has come out perfectly every time. I prefer sweet cornbread, as does most of my family, so this is lovely!!!

When I make this, though, I tend to just melt the butter in a big, non-metal bowl in the microwave. It works just as well.

Also, sometimes I'll do a little trick my dad used to do. While the oven is preheating and I'm mixing the batter, I'll put a big cast iron pan in the oven and let it heat up. Once I'm ready, I'll pull it out and pour the batter into the cast iron pan. The pan then goes back in to the oven to bake for 30 minutes. Makes a nice, crispy edge.

text:
I needed cornbread for another recipe (Nana's Squash Casserole) and somehow did not have a Jif mix.  I am a true Southerner and I do like my cornbread sweet so I searched for "sweet cornbread" and this one came up.  It was as close to a Jif mix as I could possibly make.  I baked it for 30 minutes and the edges were brown and pulled away from the pan but the center was not done.  That was okay, because it was going into another recipe immediately but for general consumption, this would have been a problem.  It did stick to the bottom of my pan also.  Instead of melting the butter in a skillet, I used my favorite plastic mixing bowl and melted the butter in the microwave and proceeded to mix everything from there.  I will make this again! ***Update - I tried this again and it came out perfect!  I don't know what I did wrong the first time but the center was cooked through this time and we really enjoyed this cornbread.  No more Jiffy mixes for me!

text:
Delicious! It is sweet, and if you want to add a contrast to the sweetness add something with heat. Perhaps a little hot sauce (sriracha), or jalepeno cheddar cheese (4 ouces give or take). 

I altered the recipes and added 1 tbsp. of onion powder, 1/2 tbsp. of dill and 4 ouces cheddar cheese. (My hubby loves those together.) He really enjoyed it. It was super moist. I cooked it for the full 40 minutes. He said the onion and dill were not that noticable so next time I'll up them both by 1/2 tbsp. and add some heat, by using the jalepeno cheddar.

He said he never had cornbread like this. I love that it's a Grandmother's recipe! Can never go wrong with Grandma's cooking!!!

text:
This wasn't the best corn bread I've ever had, nor the worst.  It was nice and moist, so wasn't lacking there in the least.  I read some of the negative reviews to get a taste for what was going on.  Some reviews said it was too salty so since I used salted butter I didn't add additional salt which was a good call.  Then others suggested cutting back the sugar because it was too sweet.  No I am not Southern and I like a sweet corn bread so I was fine with the sugar amount.  Mine did back up a little but I still found it to be a bit dense and flat in places but overall the texture was decent.  The flavor was the disappointment.  People are right it's quite a bland corn bread, a little sweet, a tiny bit of corn taste but not much.  It was okay with butter and preserves or honey on it but alone it was quite meh.  It did taste quite a bit better after giving it a short rest to cool down.

The first time I made cornbread was when I used the mix from the box. Since then, I've thought I would never make cornbread again because it's hard and bland. Yesterday, I made jambalaya and my husband said it would go well with cornbread.Oh-oh! However, I tried to find out if Allrecipes had something good on it. And I came to this recipe. Based on the good reviews, I decided to give this a try. I never buy buttermilk, so I squeezed 1 lemon and add it with milk until it filled up to 1 cup. Also,I used the iron cast skillet put in the oven. And the result? Oh, my! It's so delicious and soft. I'll absolutely keep this recipe. Thanks, Bethany :)

userID:
482759
Display Name:
Trio
isPro:

followersCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/942050.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This taste pretty close to the sweetness of Jiffy Mix, but it is SOOOOO much better.  Even the next day!  It does not have that bitter taste that a lot of cornbread recipes seem to have.

I used 1/2 cup Splenda Blend instead of sugar.  Also, I used 1/2 cup Pioneer cornmeal and 1/2 cup Bob's Red Mill cornmeal-medium grind.  This added a bit of crunch to the cornbread.

If you are baking in a cast iron skillet, remember to FIRST put your skillet in the oven to preheat.  Take it out when oven is up to temp, spray with oil, then pour batter in.  Mine takes 30 min in a preheated oven/skillet sat on a medium low oven rack.

Perfect cornbread. Seriously - to all the "southerns" who rate this recipe down,  just because you think true cornbread shouldn't be sweet, doesn't make you right. text:
This is the BEST cornbread my family has ever eaten!! I followed the recipe as directed but since I was using a dark coated 8X8 pan (sprayed with Pam), I lowered the oven to 350 and baked it for 25 minutes on Convection Bake.  It came out perfect!  I also used a low-fat cultured buttermilk (instead of a bulgarian buttermilk).  It truly was delicious along with a bowl of Red Beans and Rice! After years of trying other brands in the store where all you add is egg and milk, this is the only cornbread recipe I will ever use from now on!  Thanks Bethany for sharing this AWESOME recipe!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was great even though I kinda screwed it up. I started the recipe thinking I had regulars cornmeal. Had to make my own buttermilk as I didn't have any real on hand. When I got to the part to add cornmeal, flour, etc. I looked at my cornmeal bag and it was self-rising. So luckily I hadn't added any salt or flour yet. I added 2 c. Of the self rising mix. Omitted the salt and flour called for on the recipe. It baked for 30 minutes. Top was lightly crispy. It was a dense but sweet cornbread and my guest thought it was exceptional. Served with pork stew and/or with butter and honey. Good both ways. My goof my be my go to recipe but I would like to try this as written. Just wanted to write this review to let cooks know there's a way to use this recipe even if you don't have the exact ingredients. Followed the rest of the recipe as written. Thanks Grandma!

text:
I made this gluten dairy soy free and it was so yum for my little one. Want to share: I substituted for 4 eggs - egg whites, for white flour I substituted 1 cup potato flour, 1/4 cup quinoa flour, 1 tsp baking powder,  added 1/4 cup olive oil, for milk I used buttermilk b/c my child can EAT THAT ONCE IT IS BAKED OUT AT 400, (but I   you could try almond milk), and palm oil for the melted butter. I followed all the mixing directions in the above reciped baked at 400 for about 6 minutes (to bake out dairy) and then for the second batch reduced the heat to 350) and baked the 2nd batch for about 6 minutes. This is the most moist,non-chewy 'normal' gluten free bread i've ever had!

text:
Wonderful! I am from the south, born and raised, and my momma ALWAYS put sugar in her cornbread, so speak for yourself Kay! Hot skillet or not it doesn't matter, this is a very good recipe and my kids sit anxious by the oven waiting for it to be ready. It's a great alternative to using lard..I personally don't want pig fat in my cornbread.  You don't have to eat pig fat or shun sugar to be from the south..in fact I am enjoying this cornbread right now with my sweet tea and spicy chili that has brownSUGAR in it..*gasp*. 

I also used whole wheat organic flour and cultured raw buttermilk and it turned out amazing! Thanks for sharing and my southern family LOVES your grandmother's recipe!

text:
I LOVE this recipe!!  I had never like cornbread until I came across this!  I generally make it in the pan, but today I made mini muffins for my daughter's class.  I made a double batch and it made 108 of them (with enough batter for maybe 6 more, I'm not sure though, I didn't make anymore).  I had to play with the time a little bit.  I started with 10, next batch I went down to 9 and finished with 8 minutes.  They were a little dry with the higher cook time, but not so dry that you can't eat them.  I thought they were perfect at 8 mins.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this cornbread several times. It is a no-fail recipe. I do combine things in separate containers but it hasn't been a problem. I use the microwave to melt the butter in a pyrex measuring cup and then add the sugar and eggs to it. I combine the buttermilk and soda in another glass cup and then add it to the butter mixture. I then pour all of that over the dry ingredients. I also melt about a tablespoon of butter in my 9x13 baking dish in the oven and then pour the batter into the hot buttered pan. I like my cornbread a bit crispy and prefer thinner pieces. It is a sweet cornbread, almost like a cake but we all love it.

text:
This recipe for cornbread is one of the best ones I have tried! I followed the recipe exactly, except I baked it for only 25 minutes and then broiled the top at the end, and it came out perfect. It is moist and flavorful. A trick I have done with other cornbread in the past is to add a cup or so of canned sweet corn! And some jalapeno peppers. I haven't tried it with this recipe but I think that the sweet corn would act as at least a partial substitute for the sugar. Anyway, very delicious and I will make again!

text:
My first experience with cornbread was in a Catholic school cafeteria, and since then, I've spent my entire life saying "Ick, I hate cornbread!" But I married a southerner and decided that I really should try to give this humble food a second chance.  And oh my god am I glad I started here.  This recipe was perfect.  To suit my husband's love for the spicier things in life, I added some chopped jalapenos, green chilies and jack/cheddar cheese, but left the essence of the recipe unchanged.  I baked it in a buttered cast iron skillet for about 30-32 minutes.  My husband is still talking about it and insisted that I be sure to leave this review.  And yes, my southern boy always adds sugar to his cornbread, so to each his own I say!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great flavor.  I've been looking for a cornbread recipe as the mix I usually use has gotten really expensive.  I made this recipe the first time as it was written and liked the flavor but not the grittiness of the cornmeal.  The second time I did it as follows and had the great flavor and no grit: 

Put 1 cup cornmeal and 2 cups water in a saucepan.  Bring to a boil, then turn off heat, stir it, and let it sit until it has soaked up all the water.  Then dump it in a bowl and add all the ingredients listed (I melted the butter in the microwave).  Then you cook as directed, although I poured it on top of a pan that was about 1/3 full of homemade chili.  It came out just as good as the mix if not better.  Very moist and yummy!  I serve the cornbread chili casserole over a little chedder cheese and put butter on top.

text:
Quite frankly the best cornbread EVER!  Supermoist and a perfect companion to Blackeyed Peas, or Chili. I followed instructions and melted butter in skillet, mixed dry ingredients together seperate from the eggs and buttermilk then added all ingredients to skillet and then poured into greased pan.  Two changes, I substituted 2/3 cup of instant vanilla pudding for the sugar, and added a dollop more buttermilk.  Used Wondra flour, which is our preference.  Perfectly sweet, moist and delicious! Absolute keeper.

text:
Didn't have buttermilk, so used "soured" milk (3 Tsp vinegar per cup of homogenized milk - let sit 5 mins) and changed the cornmeal and flour proportions to 3/4 cup of cornmeal and 3/4 cup of flour and added 1/2 cup of corn flour... Makes it very light and still moist... Also recipe is easily doubled to fit in a 8" x 13" pan for 40 mins at 375 degrees.

text:
By far, this is the best cornbread recipe. I first served it with a spicy chili and it was the perfect moist, not too sweet side. The sweetness is more like a muffin, but you can always pare it back if it seems to sweet for you. My oven runs a bit hot, so I only had to cook this for 30 minutes... just be sure to check it every five minutes after 25 minutes of cooking to be sure it doesn't dry out. Finally a cornbread recipe I will use over and over again!

text:
This was my first attempt at making cornbread and my hubby and I were pretty satisfied.  We ran out of white sugar, so I used a half white sugar/half brown sugar combo, although I did cut back on the total amount of sugar because I figured the brown sugar would make it too sweet and based on other reviews. Everything else we kept the same.  Ironically, this gets 4 stars instead of 5 because we wish it had been sweeter and that the cornmeal grains had been bigger and less cake-like (maybe more like Panera/Dunkin Donuts cornbread/muffins). However, it does get 5 out of 5 stars for being super moist (we baked for 25 minutes).  Really great.  Will make again, but will get the right sugar and keep the recipe amount.  Hopefully, it will be a 5 out of 5 star recipe after that! Thanks for sharing!

I've only ever made Jiffy or other packaged corn bread mix. For a family gathering I made this recipe as written.  It was great!  I made the batter and poured it into the baking pan, took it to the party and then baked it to be fresh when we were done barbecuing. Fabulous! Thanks!  I will admit I was a little confused with the instructions but realized it was meant to be all mixed in the pan, hence removing from heat so the eggs don't cook while mixing it in.  It was simple this way and I'll be making corn bread more often now that I know how easy it can be made from scratch and I do appreciate not dirtying more bowls!

userID:

Display Name:
Christianne
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I haven't made homemade cornbread in a long time because my husband doesn't like it. Tonight I made chili so I figured now was the time to try some homemade cornbread on him. He said, "I don't normally like cornbread but I will definitely eat this."
It was a great recipe but I did tweak it a bit. I reduced the amount of sugar to 1/4 cup because I felt the amount listed was just too much. I also ground up a can of sweet white corn and mixed all the ingredients in a seasoned cast iron skillet then cooked it in the oven for 23 minutes. It came out perfectly. It held together wonderfully. Had a lightly sweet taste but still tastes like the warm, buttery cornbread my grandma use to make.

text:
I have NEVER made homemade cornbread only from a mix. I made this and it was SO easy and SOOO good! The only thing different I did was I have a 10 in WELL seasoned cast iron skillet. I melted the butter in that then mixed all ingredients in the same pan and stuck it right in the oven. Turned out PERFECT and one less dish to wash. Hubby told me I outdid myself on this one. Thanks for the recipe! Will absolutely make it again and again. Oh and by the way I am a terrible baker and this turned out picture & taste perfect should say how easy it was!

text:
This was fantastic sweet corn bread and went particularly well with my spicy black bean and chorizo chili. I mixed the ingredients exactly as the recipe suggests and used the cast iron pan cooking method that other reviewers mentioned. It came out a tad dry and probably could have cooked for a few less minutes in the oven (I did 25). But, everyone who tried it loved it and it was the favorite of several cornbreads present at the chili cookoff.

text:
I'm giving this 4 stars because I think it would have been great if I'd done the recipe exactly as called for, but because I didn't have all the ingredients on hand, I used whole wheat flour, 1 % milk and a 8 by 11 pan.  I only baked it 30 minutes but it came out very dry.  I'd give it 3 stars for the way I made it.  I think I should have cut down the baking time since I used a larger pan.  It tasted yummy though and if I microwaved individual pieces before serving it helped to soften it up.  Next time I'm going to try it in a cupcake pan (so my 4 year old will at least try it!) use buttermilk, and cut down the baking time. UPDATE: Still didn't have buttermilk but used a tablespoon of lemon juice as others suggested, used half whole wheat and half regular flour and made in cupcake pan.  I cooked them for about 15 minutes and they turned out great.  My picky boys still prefer the texture of Marie Callendars cornbread mix, but I think these are much tastier!

text:
I just got my lodge logic corn bread pan and wanted to try it out. I reduced the sugar to 1/4 cup and used Wheylow instead. Used 1/2 cut white 1/2 cup yellow cornmeal. Self rising flour so as not to mess with the baking powder but I still added a pinch of salt. Didn't use as much butter cause I just put a dab in each corn bread stick to melt it in my oven and then poured what would come out into my mix. Also added onion!! AND used a little vinegar in regular milk cause I didn't have buttermilk. I did bake it at the same temp though!!LOL GREAT!

This was the best homemade cornbread I have ever eaten.  The only thing I did differently was to melt the butter in an iron skillet and then poured into a bowl and mixed the rest of the ingredients.  Poured the contents back in the skillet, which was already greased and baked.  It only took 22 minutes to bake in an 8-inch skillet.  Wonderful recipe.  Will make from now on instead of Jiffy mix.

I melted the butter in the pan on low, so it didn't get too hot (didn't want to cook the eggs when I poured them in the butter). Very easy and yummy--never buy boxed mix again!

This is a delicious recipe. I cut the sugar to 1/2c., and think next time will use 1/2c. + 1 tbsp. of sugar for a tad more sweetness. Also, I baked it for 30 minutes @ 375 degrees, and it came out a little dry and crumbly. My oven may run hot, so I'll check it at 20 minutes next time. Will definitely make again though!

region:

country:
None
text:
Made this recipe for Thanksgiving dinner and it was a hit!  I was cooking for a large crowd so I doubled the recipe, reduced the sugar to just 1/2 cup (instead of 1 1/3), and add half a small can of corn; otherwise followed the recipe.  Baked it for 30 minutes in a 9x13 pan.  The bread was sweet enough with the reduced amount of sugar and I can't imagine how sweet it would be with the full amount.  It came out super moist and buttery, probably could have used another few minutes in the oven.  After dinner, people were smothering slices of cornbread with my homemade cranberry sauce and eating it like strawberry shortcake!

text:
First time Corn Bread maker...great recipe.  I made it this way 1/4 cup of sugar...I do not like very sweet cornbread nor does my family so 2/3 cups was too much  1/2 cup butter...It was just right  1 cup cornmeal and 1 cup Bisquick.  The Bisquick makes the cornbread rise and fluffier in the inside.   1 cup of half and half with 1 teaspoon of lemon juice. I did not have buttermilk.  I followed everything else.

country:
None
text:
Very good. I also reduced the sugar to 1/2 c, and it doesn't taste overly sweet. Making this in a mini muffin tin worked well, but it sticks to paper liners. Without the liners, it browned nicely.   If you decide to make muffins, position the rack closer to the top so they will brown, and reduce the baking time to 10 minutes for the mini ones, and test with a toothpick. Not overbaking is crucial to keeping them moist  I have tried them less sweet, as well as with a tiny ammount (1/4tsp) of fresh rosemary. Both are delicious with a dab of honey butter or plain!

text:
The cornbread came out good but I've had better so I don't know if i will try it again. I liked the fact that it required minimum prep time and easy clean up afterwards. However, I did change the recipe to accommodate to my needs: doubled amounts, used whole wheat flour instead, added 1 C of fresh corn, and decreased sugar by half. The texture was somewhat crumbly. I used a preheated cast iron skillet & total baking time was 25 min. only.

text:
I always use this recipe now for making cornbread!  I often substitue plain yogurt (Greek/European style is ideal for texture) for the buttermilk just because I am more likely to have that on hand.  A friend had made this, and I asked her for the recipe, and it's gotten a lot of compliments in the many times I've made it.  She also tossed in a can of corn to the mixed batter, and that was a nice touch.  I've added some honey or some grated cheese at times for a nice touch, and you could be creative with some fun add-ins to this great base, but it's also completely delicious and wonderful just as it is!

country:
None
text:
If you like dense cornbread like me, this is the ticket! I did not have buttermilk on hand, so I improvised by adding 2 Tbls of fresh lemon juice to one cup of low fat milk- and let that sit for about 10 minutes. It came out perfect. It is a dense cornbread as I said before, and because of that it was very filling. I doubled the batch and have one in the freezer for a future dinner, and I am so happy I did, because this now my 'go to' recipe for cornbread from now on. I served it with pork and black bean chili and it was a huge hit with everyone. (very picky eaters I might add). LOVE THIS recipe!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/299201.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
DELISH! Moist, sweet, with just enough "crunch" from the cornmeal. Like others, i reduced sugar down to 1/2 cup but I used the rest of the sugar to coat the baking pan (see below).  I didn't change anything else regarding ingredients, but couldn't bring myself to pour raw eggs into hot butter and sugar.  So I lightly whisked the eggs & added them to the buttermilk.  I added the remaining dry ingredients to the pan with the melted butter and sugar mixture and then  mixed in the buttermilk and eggs til moistened thoroughly, and poured them into an 8-inch square pan lightly that I had coated with shortening and sprinkled with granulated sugar.  It makes a delicious crunchy,slightly sweet crust.  Definitely a keeper. Simple and Yummy.

country:
None
text:
This is fantastic and I now have to make it on a weekly basis to keep my wife happy. Some substitutions: we use corn flour instead of corn meal because otherwise there are little hard bits in the bread and we were afraid of cracking a tooth. However, that substitution loses some of the texture. To restore it, use 1.5 cups corn flour and 1/2 cup of white flour instead of equal parts.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Mmm-mm-mmm-mm-mm! I can't say enough good things about this cornbread... just, wow. I cut it into eight servings, and my mum ate two in a short sitting!  I reduced the sugar to .5c, added 100g flaked almonds and 1/4c dessicated coconut, the latter because I'm trying to beat the expiry date. It turned out great! I also added 1/4c buttermilk (sour milk where I come from) to counter the added dry ingredients. I had wanted to add a large overripe banana but couldn't find it! And to think I only wanted to bake this because of the banana!  Another website includes a cup of grated cheese, which they said is optional, so maybe next time I'll add it.  This is my first real experience with cornbread (I may have eaten store-bought versions), so when it didn't change colour after 30 minutes I baked it for another 15. Next time I'll reduce the time to 35 minutes and see if it's more moist. But, WOW!

text:
This is definitly a 5 star recipe! FANTASTIC cornbread! I reduced the sugar to 1/2 cup (personal prefence). Baked for exactly 30 minutes and it was exceptionally moist, not dry or crumbly as some are. I was afraid that without baking powder it would not rise enough. When I poured the batter in the pan it seemed awful thin, but when it finished baking it had risen beautifully. Looking forward to bringing it to a chicken BBQ next week. UPDATE: I subbed maple syrup for the sugar and it was even better!!!!

text:
By far the BEST cornbread i have ever made.  Super moist, dense and oh-so sweet!! :)  The only changes I made were: 1) I was out of buttermilk so i replaced it with an equal amount of sour cream. 2) I added a little honey to the batter (because I like it really sweet.) 3) I preheated my baking pan for about 8 minutes before pouring the batter in. and 4) I baked it for only 30 minutes.    Everyone LOVED it...I can't wait to make this again! :)

text:
I love cornbread and of all the recipes I have tried in my 35 years of cooking (since I was ten?), this recipe takes the prize. I took this to a 4th of July picnic. It was devoured in 5 minutes flat.  I tried it out the night before on my husband and a bunch of teenagers. I doubled the recipe but forgot to double the flour. I loved it - very moist. When I prepared it correctly the on the 4th, it was also very delicious. The difference? On the 3rd it was quite moist and more dense. On the 4th it was still moist enough, but it was a little more crumbly like cornbread usually is. Wish I could give this recipe 10 stars.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4584574.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good, but needs to be tweaked a little for our preferences. I expected it to be buttery and crumbly, not sweet and gritty. The recipe does not state what kind of cornmeal to use so I bought "medium", which made the cornbread gritty. Definitely going to buy the "fine" one next time! Also, the sugar needs to be cut in half as I found it much too sweet. We didn't  have buttermilk but did the old milk-to-lemon juice thing as a substitute. This recipe can easily be tweaked, and I like the suggestion of adding canned corn to the bread.

None
text:
Yup. This is a very good 'yankee-cornbread' recipe. While mixing, I added the soda and buttermilk last, for a little better finish texture. I up'd the servings to 12, for a better rise in a 9 inch skillet ('kindda like a thicker cornbread). I fried a strip of smoked bacon for a little oil in the skillet (ate the bacon) and placed in the oven while preping the mix - gave it a slight rustic taste redolent of an open fire and a terriffic crust. 5 stars! Thanks Bethany!

text:
This was so good!! I didn't have any buttermilk but I made 'sour milk' by putting 1 tbsp vinegar in a measuring cup adding milk to make a cup. A lot of people don't know that buttermilk is low fat! Yes, it's basically skim milk with flavor!! Look it up. I just forgot to pick it up at the market. :-) It turned out perfect. Moist & dense, great texture & almost a crispy crust on top. Yummy! (And I've gone thru more than a few recipes looking for a decent one)

text:
Was Excellent---and shamefully simple to make! My fiance and I devoured half the recipe with steaks and salad, and the other half was gone at breakfast the following day!   This was my first cornbread, so I was cautiously optimistic. The buttermilk was JUST the right ingredient, it adds a fragrance and 'grannie-made' taste that is wonderful. The only thing I would recommend is to bake it for only about 30 min and watch it if you're oven tends to hot.   GL! It was superb.

text:
This cornbread had amazing flavor, I wish I would have followed the recipe a little more closely, or just added a bit more liquid (or maybe an extra egg).... mine turned out a little bit too crumbly for my taste, but the flavor was amazing.  I tend to always change recipes, so instead of the 1 cup butter milk I used 1/4 c whipping cream, 2/3 cup organic 2% milk, about 2-3 tablespoons sour cream, and a tablespoon of lemonjuice.  Everything else was basically the same, except I used 1/2 a cup white flour, and 1/2 a cup whole wheat flour.  I did it exactly for 30 minutes, and it was definitely ready.  The only reason I did not give a 5 was b/c i had wished it was a little less crumbly

I have made these a few times and they always come out so good!  Both times I made them, I completely forgot the buttermilk.  So I made my own buttermilk by putting two tablespoons of lemon juice and a little less than a cup of milk in a bowl.  Let it sit for five minutes and its instant buttermilk.  The cornbread still tastes great too!  My husband eats these until they are all gone.  Its a keeper!

Used original recipe's ingredients/yield except that... (1) I used 4 TBSPs SACO powdered cultured buttermilk mixed with 1 cup water, and (2) I used 3/4 of the required 2/3 cup white sugar. Baked it using a 9"-diameter, 1-1/2" tall round non-stick baking pan. Served it with "Honey Butter". Love it! NEXT TIME I'll... (1) Lower the oven temp from 375F to about 325F to 350F (2) Use 1/2 cup white sugar instead of 2/3 cup (3) Try another reviewer's ratio suggestion of 1-1/4 cup cornmeal & 3/4 cup flour.
Thanks for the recipe & reviews! :-)

text:
I made it just as written except for two things. First I'm of the old school and I mixed the flour, cornmeal, and salt in a bowl separately before adding it to the liquid. The other change I would not have made, except my oven has gone on the fritz. The repair man said it will take up to two months to repair my oven, possibly sooner. So I cooked the cornbread in a cast iron skillet on the stove for about 30 minutes on low. My children loved it. I was very relieved to see that it turned out. If you do it on the stove make sure it has a lid and butter the pan after it is hot.  Thank you grandma for a wonderfull cornbread!!

This is a delicious cornbread that is very moist.  I did make some adaptions that increased the nutritional content significantly. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have searched for a great tasting corn bread recipe and this is it!  That said, I did not follow the directions for preparing.  I followed the simple muffin method.  Mix all dry ingredients together in one bowl.  Mix wet ingredients in another (make sure buttermilk and eggs are not straight-out-of-the fridge cold or the butter will get grainy.  I mix the buttermilk and eggs together in a 2-cup measuring cup then microwave for 20 seconds just to take the chill off).  Add wet ingredients to dry and mix JUST UNTIL BLENDED.  Do not overmix!  I baked this at 400 degrees for 25 minutes.  Yum!
Review:

5

text:
I made this recipe the first time exactly as written and it was absolutely wonderful.  It was moist and sweet, just like my family loves it.  It went perfectly with the spicy chili it was served with.  Second time I made it I doubled the recipe and put it in a 9x13 pan.  When I baked it the edges were getting too done and the center stayed raw so I would suggest sticking with the size pans the recipe calls for.  I will definatley make this recipe over and over again.

text:
WOW!  I decided to try this recipe out on our church congregation at our annual Thanksgiving dinner to see how it went over!!!  It went over fabulously!  Moist and sweet!  One woman came up to me and said that it was the best cornbread she had ever had!  I varied the recipe by using 1/2 cup white flour & 1/2 cup whole wheat flour, doubled the recipe, put it in a 9" x 13" cast iron pan and baked it for 30-35 minutes!  Am now going to make it for our family Thanksgiving Day dinner....thanks for a wonderful recipe!

text:
This stuff was AMAZING! I mean, CRAZY AMAZING!  The only variance I did from the original recipe was as such: I didn't have buttermilk (not something we keep laying around the house), so I used a substitution I found. 1 tablespoon white vinegar to just under 1 cup milk.  I used 2% for the fat content (almost always when cooking), and just added the vinegar, let it sit for a few minutes, and add as you would buttermilk.  The difference is unnoticeable.  I will be making this every time I make chili.  The recipe I reviewed on this site for Chili is by far the best!!  A great pairing!

text:
This cornbread came out dense, gorgeous and delicious. I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 because as written it would've been way too sweet. I reduced it to 1/2 cup and it was still a little sweeter than I prefer. It helps to use a small pot/saucepan to melt the butter in and mix your ingredients in there and to preheat your pan while you do. I'll definitely use this recipe again.

text:
I find that sometimes the simplest things to make are the best things to eat. So is the case with this cornbread. It was just flawlessmoist, sweet, and classic. I cut down on the sugar by about 1/4 cup so that I could replace it with honey, which added a little more depth of flavor to it. I also found this recipe as easy to throw together as packaged cornbread mixes so I will never go back. I topped my piece with homemade honey butter and devoured it before I even got my chili into the bowl. Very delicious!

text:
This recipe is PERFECT!! I followed the instructions and quantities exactly and the cornbread was a HIT! The only thing I changed was that I used a non-stick muffin tray to make mini-cornbreads. The recipe makes exactly 24 muffins - perfect individual serving sizes! I had cornmeal and buttermilk left the next day, so I made as many batches as I could with what was left-over and delivered to my neighbours. They all loved it!! Oh, the only other thing I noticed that my cooking time had to be lowered to only 18-20 mins as my oven is pretty powerful.   The cornbread still tastes fresh today - Wednesday (and I made this batch on Monday!).  Amazing recipe!!

Never made homemade cornbread from scratch. I happened to buy a big bag of freshly milled cornmeal at a county fair and decided this was time. I used PAM in a 9-in and followed recipe except for reducing to 1/2 c. sugar and whole wheat flour instead of white. I also baked for only 20 mins. I couldn't stop taste-testing it. text:
I have tried several cornbread recipes from this site and this one will probably be my go to recipe.  It came out really good with whole wheat flour and cooking in a cast iron skillet.  Thankfully, I couldn't taste the baking soda as I can in many other recipes.  It was a little dense and sweet for my taste so I will probably cut the sugar back next time and sift my flour.  Otherwise this one is a keeper.

Update:  I don't know what I did differently besides lowering the temperature on my oven, but about the 3rd time I made it, but it was WONDERFUL!  This the cornbread recipe for me.  

If you cut the recipe in half it fits perfectly in an 8in cast iron skillet.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am holding onto this recipe for good!  I had all of the ingredients on hand, and it was so simple to make.  I cut up the stick of butter and melted it in a large bowl in the microwave.  Also, I mixed the cornmeal with the buttermilk and let it soak for a minute.  Then, I mixed everything together in the bowl, poured it into a deep dish (greased with butter) and baked it for 30 minutes.  Once it came out and cooled for 5 or 10 minutes, I lightly buttered the top to keep it moist.  And moist it was!  So delicious!  I am a midwestern girl, but I had plenty of this with some southern sweet tea...the best!

I have a plea for help: I've made this cornbread using whole wheat flour about 10 times. The first 5 times that I made it, it turned out perfect. I cooked it for the full 40 minutes, and it tasted great and held very well while cutting and eating.  Unfortunately, the last 5 times that I've made this, the substance of the cornbread has dramatically changed. But the only difference in what I am doing with the cornbread is to cook it with whole milk instead of 2%. When I make it now, it does not hold very well, and the bottom crest is very crumbly. It's still delicious; just not very substantive.   I've tried altering the cooking time, etc. What am I doing wrong??

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/811048.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is very very good cornbread.  I did not give it 5 stars though.  I would give it 4.5 or 4.75 if I could.  The reason is I am looking for a cornbread that is dense and moist and sweet.  This is sweet but crumbly, not dense and moist.  To the recipe's credit it could be me, my oven, or the type of pan I used.  But I watched it carefully and after 30 minutes a toothpick came out covered in batter so I let it go another 6 minutes.  Maybe it only needed 3?  I will try a couple others from this site, they are very similar except they use baking powder, not soda, regular milk, not buttermilk, and vegetable oil, not butter.  Coincidently if anyone out there is from the Rochester, NY area and has ever had cornbread from Beale Street Cafe, THAT'S the type of cornbread I'm looking for!

text:
This is my new favorite cornbread recipe. It's so easy to make and is just sweet enough without being too sweet. One tip I can offer - when I added the dry ingredients, I gradually whisked in the cornmeal first, then sifted the flour and salt into the pan as I stirred. I had no lumps to deal with and the result was divine! Thanks for a keeper!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the only cornbread recipe that I make.  I do cut the sugar down to 1/2 a cup.  I found that if you let your butter brown in your pan, it gives the cornbread a rich, almost caramel-y taste.  Just be careful not to burn it.  I never have buttermilk on hand so I add 1-2 Tbsp of vinegar to sour some regular milk.  It works every time.  I often substitute some of the white flour for whole wheat, ground flax seed, and/or masa harina to give it some variation.  It's hard to mess up this great recipe.

Thank you so much for such a fast, easy and delicious recipe!  This is exactly what I was hoping for- good, cakelike consistency, just enough sweetness, and it held together like a dream! I followed the recipe to a "T" (except for subbing 1 cup whole milk with 1 T vinegar to sour it, because I had no buttermilk) and we served it with the Best Vegetarian Chili in the World from this site, and it hit the spot on a frigid Chicago night.

I don't understand how so many of you can give this five stars if you changed it as much as you did, but I made this without substitutions and I absolutely loved it. Sweet, holds up together great, and went really well with the porkchops and gravy I made for dinner. It's also an easy, quick snack; cut it in half, sprinkle some cheddar cheese over it, and heat it up until the cheese melts. I'm never using Jiffy box mix again.

text:
The first time I made this, I baked the cornbread in the same cast iron skillet I mixed the ingredients in, but it didn't quite turn out right.  The second time I followed the instructions and baked it in a separate pan and it turned out awesome!  Not sure why there is a difference, but there was.  This is a moist, sweet cornbread - just to my liking!  Edited to say that the 3rd time I made this, I added 1 cup of creamed corn - YUM!  Made it only slightly more moist. . . could've used some diced jalepenos or green chiles!

text:
I couldn't upload a photo, because there are only three crumbs left.  It came out as beautiful as the photo shown though, and the taste.. perfection!  I like my cornbread more on the cakey* side and not very gritty, so I used fine cornmeal, and i didn't have buttermilk, only light milk, so i gave it a shot of lemon juice before i began and followed the recipe to a *T*.  Well, I accidentally put in a tsp. b. soda, but it didn't hurt the recipe at all.  We had it with chili tonight, but i buttered and honeyed a small square for desert, heh.  Truly, I have made a lot of cornbread but this is the best.  Thank goodness for your granny!  Thanks for the recipe, its going into the family file. (trust me, not many make it in there).  ~~bc

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this cornbread for a dinner party last night and it was a big hit!  I just made a few changes which turned out great. I only used 1/3 cup sugar (it was sweet enough with this!), added half a can (about 8oz) creamed corn, cut down on the buttermilk to about 3/4cup. This is by far the best cornbread I've made. Just a tip, I melted the butter in the microwave in a large glass bowl, and had the other ingredients ready to go, rather than cooking it on the stove.  So easy!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
Just pulled a double batch of this out of the oven and my house smells heavenly.  I needed cornbread to "go with" stew for lunch tomorrow and decided to try this recipe rather than using a mix. I am not a cornbread eater but my husband, who is, has been circling the kitchen for the last 15 minutes slicing off pieces and declaring this the best cornbread he's ever eaten.  So, thought I should log on and give this 5 stars.  I made the recipe exactly as given except that I mixed milk with vinegar rather than buying buttermilk.  It is incredibly easy...I combined all ingredients in the pan I melted the butter in.  Thanks for sharing this recipe.

text:
I have made this several times exactly as written. It's awesome!  Last time, though, I decided to try an easier way.  I melted the butter in a large plastic bowl in the microwave.  I then added the rest of the ingredients to the same bowl.  I cooked it in a pre-heated cast-iron skillet for 25 minutes.  It was fantastic!  Using the microwave with only one bowl definitely made less of a mess, and it tasted just as wonderful as the original.  This is the only cornbread recipe I will ever use!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I can't put into words how great this cornbread is!  So moist...just the right amount of sweetness...nice slightly crunchy outside.  I don't even like cornbread, but my daughter does and I wanted to be able to make her some great homemade cornbread.  I made this last night after eating dinner and I just had to have three pieces of it!  I followed the recipe exactly as stated with a few "quick and easy" steps just for my purposes: Melted my butter in a saucepan instead of a skillet because I didn't think my skillet would be deep enough to mix everything without making a mess. Beat the eggs before adding them to the butter and sugar mixture. Mixed the flour, cornmeal and salt together in a small bowl before adding them to the saucepan.  I also used unflavored Crisco shortening to grease my pan and I did use salted butter in the recipe.  Yummy, yummy, yummy!  I think they'd be awesome as mini-muffins and am going to buy a mini-muffin pan today.  Thanks for a super recipe!

text:
This is absolutely my favorite cornbread recipe! I have found that making it in a preheated cast-iron skillet makes it even better. Since the skillet is preheated (I just stick it in the oven after I turn it on, and when I'm done mixing the cornbread I take out the pan and pour in the batter) it doesn't need to cook as long. Could be my oven, but this cornbread is done in exactly 15 minutes. It is so delicious! Thank you for this recipe!

text:
I've been looking for a good cornbread recipe that measures up to my husbands mothers recipe.  Well I finally found it with this one!  I followed the recipe almost to the T except I followed the advise of another and substituted 1 can of Creamed Corn in place of the buttermilk and I added a bit of evaporated milk and cut down the sugar to about 1/4 cup as my husband doesn't like his cornbread too sweet!! And as always I use a cast iron pot in the oven so I just mixed everything up in a bowl and preheated my cast iron pot with the butter till it got warmed and then poured everything in the pot. I made this before I left for my son's football game and I served this with the Fantastic Black Bean Chili recipe found on this site also!!! The cornbread was so
yummy!! It was the perfect meal after being out in the cold at the Football Game!! Oh by the way the Cornbread disappeared! Thanx so much for this recipe.

text:
Best cornbread ever!  i used an 8 inch skillet.  when i make cornbread, i put about 2-3 tablespoons of shortening in the skillet and put in the oven while it preheats.  when the oven has preheated, take out your skillet and pour in the cornbread mixture.  it will cook a little instantly and will give you a perfectly crisp crust.

Just "because" I'd like to try adding whole corn and green chilis.  I will report back on that if I do.  It truly is wonderful the way it is, we just like the texture of the additions.  Thanks so much for a true winner!
10/31/11  Well, it took me a year, but I did double the recipe, added 2 c. frozen corn, thawed and 2-4 oz. cans diced chilis.  I melted the butter in a huge (15") cast iron skillet (I sprayed up the sides with Pam) and just mixed it all up in their, too.    40 minutes later, it was perfectly nice and moist.  I'm almost afraid to push the envelope, but I'm tempted to add shredded cheddar to it.  Straight or with the additions, this is one keeper recipe!  Thank you so much for sharing.  It's the only one I'll ever use now.  Folks are always asking me to make this.

text:
Very good cornbread, but I read it as 1/4 cup of butter (1/2 stick) instead of 1/4 lb.   So, I ended up with a drier, but still yummy cornbread.  So, if you are trying to watch your butter intake, rest assured that you will get a good result with 1/2 the amount of butter.

text:
My daughter loves cornbread, so I looked up this recipe to try and go "mixless".  I was a little worried because of the reviews that it might be fussy. I tried it using the hot iron skillet method and it was amazingly good. I was telling my mom how good it was and she mentioned my grandpa loved cornbread, but couldn't find a mix he liked. I said I'd make him a batch and of course my dad would also need one.  I still had buttermilk so I went to work and now I can make it easily from memory and it's so worth washing a pan and an iron skillet. I make enough each time to use the buttermilk up and freeze what we don't eat.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
One thing I have to say: Wow. This makes the most AMAZING cornbread I have ever had. I followed the recipe as-is, except I only had self-rising corn meal, and a 10" round cast iron skillet. Greased the skillet liberally with veg. oil, left some in the bottom, and popped it in the oven to preheat while I mixed all of the ingredients in my saucepan. When melting the butter, I turn off the gas JUST before it's all melted, and it just melts its self. Kept following directions, take the skillet out of the oven [HOT!], and pour it in. Into the oven, and after 25 minutes, it's perfect. I made the first batch, brought it over to a friend's, and it was gone the following day. Just made another batch two hours ago for breakfast =)

text:
The last time I made cornbread it came out dry and bland.  This recipe tasted like it was store bought!  I used a little less sugar than called, and might use a touch less next time to play with it.  I added a few handfuls of frozen corn into the mix.  I did not have a cast-iron skillet, so I greased the 8 in pan with vegetable oil and popped it into the pre-heating oven while I mixed the rest of the ingredients in the same pot I melted the butter in.  Baked up beautifully in under 30 minutes.  The taste is moist, and just sweet enough.  Quite yummy!  Great recipe!  Thanks!

I thought this was very good.  I didn't have buttermilk, so I made it using 1 cup of milk + 1 tablespoon white vinegar, and *believe it or not* I didn't have eggs, so I substituted 3 tablespoons of mayo for each egg.  I also used corn flour, as for some reason I had a hard time finding cornmeal.  It turned out beautifully!  A keeper fo' sure.

text:
I don't know what happened to the people that said it was dry, but mine was moist and perfect. I thought it seemed like a lot of sugar, but it wasnt. It had the right amount of sweetness. I ended up making a double batch for my husband to take to work with my homemade chili. It was a hit. I never thought about buttermilk in cornbread, but it's great. I made sure to let my butter cool before I added the eggs. I saw that people commented about it scrambling the eggs. Will be making again soon. Thanks

text:
Really good - soft and moist with a corny crunch. I cooked as a dozen muffins for 15 min. Since we have a child with a dairy allergy, I used half shortening and half reg. smartbalance in place of butter. Mixed plain soymilk with 1 1/2 tsp lemon juice to equal 1 cup and used in place of buttermilk. Even with these substitutions, it was delicious.

Delicious!  I grind the corn into meal myself and soak it in the buttermilk (or homemade kefir if that is what I have).  I also use whole wheat flour as I mill that too.  Wow, is it yummy.  You honestly have not really had good cornbread until you have made it with freshly ground corn.  This recipe does the ingredients justice.  I usually cut back on the sugar quite a bit, but sometimes I forget and my family loves it either way.

text:
I scaled this recipe to 36 so I could make it at my work (I work at an assisted living facility with 36 residents) and it went over really well. However, the first time it was a little too sweet, so the second time (and everytime after) I used only 2 cups sugar as opposed to the 2 2/3 cups called for in the recipe. I guess for the regular recipe I would use only 1/2 cup suger. It's moist, fluffy and sweet, with great flavor. This one is definately a keeper, the only way I will make cornbread again. Also makes great cornbread dressing- I bake the seasonings and onions and celery in the cornbread to save the extra step, and everyone loves it!

text:
I really liked this recipe!  I was looking for a slightly sweeter cornbread, and this fits perfectly!  I have made it both as written (which is very good) and with a few substitutes.  Half whole-wheat flour/half white, splenda instead of sugar, and a no-transfat margarine instead of the butter, and it still works splendidly!  The texture is slightly different, but I think you run into that with the change in flour.  I dropped the cooktime down to about 25 minutes, but I have a little convection oven that cooks things like this at a super-sonic speed!

THis recipe is fantastic.  It has become my standard recipe for breakfast cornbread.  I eat it with come butter and jelly, or butter and honey and it's wonderful.  A tip, a don't ever buy buttermilk, but I do make homemade yogurt and I substitute plain yogurt for the buttermilk.  I also add the baking soda to the yogurt before I do anything else to help it rise even more.  Not sure if it makes a diffference, but this recipe is great with the yogurt, I'd suggest Stoneyfield if you dont make your own.

An okay basic recipe but not at all moist.  I used 1/2c sugar as other reviews suggested because they felt it was too sweet; next try I will use more sugar as well as make an addition for a moist cornbread.  I added 1T of Sour Cream which was a good addition.  We all have various tastes so we can make our own adjustments to fit that.  Thx for sharing your recipe Bethany.
Review:

text:
Perfect!!!! It's all I hoped this recipe would be -- sweet, moist, chewy, and easy! I'd never made cornbread from scratch before and now I'll never do the mix again! I thought making it from scratch would take a long time and be complicated. This recipe was almost as easy as getting the mix -- which always tastes bland and is too crumbly. I love this cornbread! We're having leftovers tonight with our taco soup! The only change I did was half the ingredients and put it in a smaller, white porcelain baking dish. Plenty for two people!

text:
I started making a single batch and then by mistake doubled the buttermilk. So, after that I added double of everything else except sugar and butter. I baked in a 13x9 for 40 minutes and it turned out way good with a good crispy crust to it. The inside could have been a little more moist, but that is probably due to my mistake of not doubling the butter. I tried to make up for it by serving it with honey butter and I think it worked. :-)
